Ever since their creation, cars have been the main method of transportation. However, in recent times cars have become less popular because of the issues that they cause. Limited car use would be very advantageous because vehicles discourage physical activity, make pollution, and cost everyone money.  An advantage of limiting the use of cars is that they discourage physical activity. Reliance on a motorized vehicle for transportation from place to place results in little to no physical activity. Cars have replaced the use of bicycles, skateboards, and regular walking, their use seemingly reserved only for the youth. In a car free society such as Vaunban, Germany, the "swish of bicycles and the chatter of wandering children" can be heard by anyone walking down the street Source 1. This clearly shows that when cars are used less, people engage in more physical activity. This is the same case for Bogota, Columbia where the Day Without Cars is a big hit. Just in the third year of this event, over 118 miles of bicycle paths have been constructed in the city Source 3. Limiting the use of cars is definetely advantageous because they discourage physical activity.  Limiting the use of cars would be incredibly beneficial because they make pollution. The billions of vehicles in the world create unbelievable amounts of pollution. In Europe, "passenger cars are responsible for 12 percent of greenhouse gas emissions" and "up to 50 percent... in the United States" Source 1. The pollution from the increasing amounts of cars in compacted areas "are chocking cities" Source 1. Nearly nothing else creates that much pollution. The only thing that cars are second to in the pollution rates are the monstrous power plants that continuously belch smoke into the atmosphere Source 4. If the use of vehicles decreases, then "it will have beneficial implications for carbon emissions and the environment" Source 4. This evidence clearly supports that the use of vehicles is causing a huge amount of pollution. Thus, limiting the use of cars would be incredibly beneficial because they make pollution.  Decreased use of automobiles would be extremely advantageous because the they cost everyone money. Expenses such as constant maintanance and fuel cost the average car owner a large chunk of their salary. In April 2013, the average miles driven per person was down by 9 percent, equivalent to the rate in January 1995 Source 4. The most likely cause is that "cashstrapped Americans could not afford new cars" Source 4. The high cost of cars and their maintanace is a huge burden on the backs of the average vehicle owner. Not only does vehicles cost the individual person, but they have large effects on the government. In the sixyear federal transportation bill, the cost of the highways was 80 percent, and only 20 percent was available to all other forms of transportation Source 1. This issue has caused the legislators to get involved with the problem. Obviously, decreasing the amount of automobiles would be extremely advantageous because they cost everyone money.  Limited car use would be very advantageous because vehicles discourage physical activity, make pollution, and cost everyone money.		0
Studying Venus Remains Worth Pursuing Despite Challenges   The author makes a compelling case that studying Venus warrants continued efforts in spite of the planet's harsh environmental dangers. While exploring Venus poses clear risks, the potential scientific rewards strongly support ongoing exploration as a worthy endeavor.   Several key points in the article back up this assessment. The author notes how little is still understood about Venus' geology, atmosphere and climate history compared to other planets. Given Venus' similarities to Earth in size and composition, gaining new insights about its development and evolution could offer perspective on our own world. Unraveling Venus' mysteries may also deepen understanding of atmospheric greenhouse effects and how terrestrial planets evolve generally. These knowledge fronts present opportunities for major scientific advances with relevance beyond Venus alone.  Of course, any planetary exploration comes with hazards and Venus' extreme conditions raise the risks significantly. Surface temperatures hot enough to melt lead and an atmosphere over 90 times denser than Earth's pose obvious formidable challenges. However, the article outlines ongoing technological progress developing materials and craft designs able to better withstand such pressures and temperatures - progress that could eventually enable surface missions. Robotic orbiters in the meantime can still collect valuable atmospheric data without immediate risks to human life.   Considering the rich potential rewards to science outweighing even serious dangers, the case is strong that studying Venus merits continued dedicated efforts. Although risks cannot be eliminated entirely, steady progress refining Venus-ready technologies suggests the rewards remain achievable through careful, cautious approaches. Venus thus still represents a planetary frontier very much still worth humanity's dedicated efforts to explore and uncover the mysteries within our own planetary neighbor.		1
The author suggests that studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the danger. Throughout the article, the author supports this claim very well. The author gives a few real benefits for exploring Venus. The author continuously tells us, the readers, about advancing technology thanks to human curiosity. The author even gives problems and solutions to explore Venus.  At the end of the article, paragraph 8, the author says, "Striving to meet the challenges presented by Venus has value, not only because of the insight to be gained on the planet itself, but also because human curiosity will likely lead us into many equally intimidating endeavors." This means that by exploring Venus, we will gain knowledge and be prepared for future missions with similar conditions. Paragraph 4 talks about Venus's past like how it "may well once have been the most Earth-like planet in our solar system." With knowledge of Venus's past, we could not only learn about Venus more, but we could use that information and compare it to Earth to predict some of Earth's future. That is how Venus's benefits outweighs its dangers.  In paragraph 7, it talks about NASA's interest to study Venus. In doing so, NASA is creating better technology and pushing the human race further. "For example, some simplified electronics made of silicon carbide have been tested in a chamber simulating the chaos of Venus's surface and have lasted for three weeks in such contitions." With advancing technology thanks to the interest in Venus, we can now create objects that can survive over 800 degrees Fahrenheit on Venus's surface for three weeks. That is how studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the dangers because we advance with the study.  Throughout the article, many problems are brought up with solutions. For example, paragraph 3 talks about Venus's dangerous conditions that aren't fit for humans, but in paragraph 5, NASA believes they can solve this problem by allowing scientists to float above the chaotic conditions which would allow humans to go to Venus and study it better. Paragraph 6 introduces the problem that humans wouldn't be able to gather a lot of information if they are on a ship orbiting Venus because of its dense atmosphere. In paragraph 7, the article says, "systems that use mechanical parts can be made more resistant to pressure, heat, and other forces." Paragraph 7 gives us the solution to the problem in paragraph 6. This in turn can also relate to the fact that our technology would advance thanks to the planning for Venus. That is how the author supports his claim by giving us problems and solutions to explore Venus, which negates some of the dangers.  With insight from Venus, advancing technology, and solutions to problems, the author supports his claim. The author tells us about benefits of exploring Venus. The author tells us how technology would advance thanks to the curiosity humans possess for Venus. The author tells us solutions to problems which negates some of the dangers. Therefore, the author supports his claim very well since he gave reasons why the study of Venus is a worthy pursuit, and why some of the dangers aren't a big enough threat to stop humans.		0

Title: Group Work vs. Individual Work: Which is Better for Students?  As an 8th grader, I have experienced both group work and individual work in my academic journey. While some students might prefer working alone, I believe that working in a group has more benefits for students. Here are some reasons why.  Firstly, group work allows students to learn from each other. When working in a group, we can share our ideas and perspectives, and learn from each other's strengths and weaknesses. For example, if one group member is good at math, they can help the others with their math problems. This not only helps the individual students, but also fosters a sense of collaboration and teamwork.  Secondly, group work encourages communication and social skills. When working in a group, we have to communicate effectively to reach a common goal. This means listening to each other, expressing our ideas clearly, and resolving conflicts in a respectful manner. These skills are essential for success in any field, and can help students become better communicators and team players.  Thirdly, group work can be more fun and engaging than individual work. When working alone, students can get bored or lose motivation easily. But when working in a group, students can motivate and inspire each other, making the work more enjoyable and rewarding. For example, if one group member is struggling with a project, the others can offer support and encouragement to help them finish it.  Finally, group work can lead to better learning outcomes. When students work together, they can share their knowledge and experiences, and learn from each other's approaches. This can result in more creative and innovative solutions to problems, and can lead to better grades and academic performance.  In conclusion, while some students might prefer working alone, I believe that working in a group has more benefits for students. Group work promotes collaboration, communication, social skills, and creativity, and can lead to better learning outcomes. So, the next time you have a project or assignment, consider working with a group  ?you might be surprised at how much you can achieve together!		1

Phones and Driving  Upon the development of handheld computers, more commonly known as "smart phones," the question arises whether, when driving, they are a necessity or a deterrent. Both sides of the argument induced by this question are accurate in some way and folly in another; and so there will always be debate over the subject, with both sides just as right and just as wrong as the other for different reasons. To elaborate upon this further, one might argue that phones should not be allowed in motorized vehicles while they are being operated due to the implication of a distraction. On the other hand, however, one might also argue the necessity of GPS and availability for work. Some laws are put in place to help prevent accidents through negligence because of the need to sometimes carry a device; the only trouble is that people abuse the rights they do have and many can be found texting or holding a phone up to their ear with only one hand or nothing but their knee on the steering wheel. Not only do those drivers have less control of the steering wheel, but they also often get distracted by conversation and drive recklessly. These individuals are the ones the counter argument against phones in motor vehicles will often refer to. The argument about phones and driving is controversial to say the least, and while often neglected it is important to carefully analyze all factors contributing before speaking or constructing an argument or opinion about the subject.  Cell phones did not exist when cars were first beginning to be produced on a massive scale in 1908 with Henry Ford's Model T, and wouldn't exist for another sixty five years after its development. Laws were never necessary for the implication of cellphones because they did not yet exist, but when cellphones were invented they, in certain cases, became a real problem for people on the road. Since then the cell phone has advanced in an amazing way, rather than a big brick . The first computer was a enormous invention, large enough that one could easily fill an entire room. Today, we have advanced so much on the principle of the computer that we have eventually developed a hand held portable computer that is now in everybody's pockets. Also to be noted is that the first cellular phone was by no means the super computers they are today; they too were big and bulky, and were only good for making phone calls like an ordinary telephone. These amazing advancements have become the very necessities we rely on today, the great majority of which developed only in recent years, and are now staples of modern society.  The most controversial subject outside of laws already put in place about cell phones and driving is manner of necessity, and manner of liability.  There is no one correct party in this argument, because there is always a valid and considerable counter argument to every point which can be made on either which side; wherefore every argument which can be made is only a half truth. The folly of individuals on both polarities of the argument is the inability to understand the importance or reason behind any opinion that in any way opposes their own. The fact of the matter is, neither of which party is entirely correct in their accusations based on the bias of their opinion on the subject. Cell phones are an important and useful tool, whether you need to carry one at all times for work or simply the convenience of having a device with which you can get ahold of outside sources in dire conditions and utilize the availability of GPS if needed. People should most certainly keep their cell phones with them while their driving; but people are often known to abuse this right by recklessly focusing on their device at unnecessary times when driving. To utilize your device properly is the best option rather than to follow each extreme of all or nothing, but the problem still stands and will always stand for the sheer fact that motorized vehicles and cell phones simply exist that there will be those who will not follow this code of conduct, despite any laws which could be implemented.  The general population needs to be encouraged somehow to go about their business responsibly. Unfortunately, this is next to impossible to achieve by any conceivable means on a large scale, and certainly impossible to convince every individual entirely. This will always be a problem in society with any and all causes, and it is up to the rest to withhold these laws and maintain both order and safety. The only thing people can truly do to resolve a situation where somebody is recklessly driving due to negligence while texting or otherwise using their mobile device, is to report the incident to law enforcement for the safety of other individuals on the road. Motorized vehicles are a wonderful utility but they are unsafe, accidents can happen simply by not being careful and often result in death or serious injury.  The best and only thing we can do is to just drive with caution and alertness at all times, especially considering that people are unpredictable and anything can happen on the road.  \  3 1      		0
 Car-free cities are becoming increasingly popular worldwide. There are many advantages to limiting car usage within cities, including reduced traffic congestion, improved air quality, and increased exercise for citizens. In this essay, I will explore the benefits of car-free cities, and examine the reasons why they are on the rise.  One significant advantage of a car-free city is reduced traffic congestion. Cars are responsible for a significant portion of rush hour traffic, and cities that have implemented car-free policies have seen a significant decrease in congestion. This decrease in congestion leads to quicker travel times for public transportation and cycling, two alternative modes of transportation that become more appealing in car-free cities. Additionally, car-free cities often have broader and more efficient public transportation systems, allowing people to get around even quicker than they would if they were driving a car, in addition to the fact that a fewer number of cars means less waiting time at traffic lights.  Another advantage of car-free cities is improved air quality. Cars are a significant source of air pollution, including carbon monoxide, nitrogen oxides, and particulate matter. By reducing the number of cars on the road, cities limit the amount of pollution that is released into the air. This improvement in air quality leads to healthier citizens and a better environment. In addition to the reduction in pollution, noise levels are also decreased in car-free cities, contributing to a cleaner and more peaceful environment.  Car-free cities have also been found to lead to increased exercise for citizens. In cities where car usage is limited, people are encouraged to walk, cycle, or use public transportation instead of driving. This increase in activity resulting from a car-free city leads to more physically active citizens, with associated health benefits, such as lower rates of obesity and cardiovascular disease.  There are also economic benefits to car-free cities. Car ownership and maintenance can be expensive, and car-free cities allow individuals and businesses to save money on these expenses. Additionally, car-free cities often see an increase in tourism, as the reduced congestion and improved air quality make them more attractive to visitors. The increase in tourism can bring economic benefits to the city, including increased employment opportunities and revenue generation.  In conclusion, car-free cities are becoming increasingly popular worldwide, and they offer many advantages. By reducing traffic congestion, improving air quality, and increasing exercise for citizens, car-free cities contribute to a cleaner, healthier, and more sustainable environment. Additionally, car-free cities can save individuals and businesses money on car ownership and maintenance, and can bring economic benefits to the city in the form of increased tourism. As such, cities worldwide are exploring the possibilities of car-free polices to bring about these advantages.		1

Work: When you're positive, you're more productive, creative, and better at solving problems. In recent years, some schools have incorporated meditation and mindfulness practices into their daily routines. While some may believe that these practices are beneficial, I am against their inclusion in schools for a number of reasons.  First and foremost, I do not believe that meditation and mindfulness practices have a place in the academic setting. Schools are meant to be places of learning, where students can develop important skills and knowledge that will prepare them for their future lives and careers. Meditation and mindfulness practices, on the other hand, are typically associated with spirituality and personal growth. While these practices may be valuable for some individuals, they do not belong in a school setting.  Furthermore, I believe that there are better ways for schools to help students develop important skills like focus, concentration, and stress management. For example, schools could offer classes on time management, organization, and study skills. These classes would be more directly relevant to students' academic experiences, and would be more likely to help students succeed in their studies.  Finally, I worry that the inclusion of meditation and mindfulness practices in schools could lead to some students feeling uncomfortable or excluded. These practices are often associated with specific religious or cultural traditions, and not all students may feel comfortable participating in them. Additionally, some students may simply not be interested in meditation or mindfulness practices, and may feel pressured to participate in order to fit in with their peers.  In conclusion, while some may argue that meditation and mindfulness practices have a place in schools, I believe that they do not belong in the academic setting. Schools should focus on providing students with the skills and knowledge they need to succeed academically and professionally, rather than incorporating spiritual practices that may not be relevant or inclusive for all students.		1

 The electoral college is a system used in the United States to elect the president. It is composed of 538 electors, divided among the 50 states and the District of Columbia. The electors are chosen by each state's political party, and each state has a number of electors equal to the number of its Senators and Representatives in Congress.  One of the main criticisms of the electoral college is that it can be unfair to smaller states. While larger states have more electoral votes, smaller states have just as much sway over the outcome of the election. This is because one elector from a state can determine the outcome of the election, so even though smaller states have fewer electors, they can still have a significant impact on the outcome.  Another criticism is that it can be difficult for third-party candidates to succeed. In the Electoral College system, a candidate needs to win at least 270 electoral votes to be elected president. This can make it difficult for smaller, third-party candidates to succeed, as they may not get enough support to reach that number. This can lead to the election of two candidates with differing viewpoints, which could result in a government that does not reflect the will of the people.  However, supporters of the electoral college argue that it preserves the principles of national unity and federalism. In the Electoral College system, all states are given a voice, regardless of their population. This means that rural states and urban states, as well as large states and small states, all have a say in the election. Additionally, some argue that the electoral college provides a check on the influence of major cities and metropolitan areas on the election.  In conclusion, the electoral college is a system used to elect the president in the United States. It has both its positive and negative aspects. While it can be unfair to smaller states and difficult for third-party candidates to succeed, it also preserves the principles of national unity and federalism. It is up to policymakers to consider the best way to improve the election process and ensure that it reflects the will of the people.		1
**The Challenge of Exploring Venus: Evaluating the Author's Support for Studying Venus Despite the Dangers**  In his article ‚ÄúThe Challenge of Exploring Venus, ?David Grinspoon argues that studying Venus is a worthy pursuit despite the dangers it presents. He cites several reasons for this, including the planet‚Äôs proximity to Earth, its potential habitability, and its unique geology. However, Grinspoon‚Äôs argument is not without its flaws. He downplays the dangers of Venus‚Äôs atmosphere and surface conditions, and he fails to adequately address the ethical concerns that arise from sending humans to explore the planet.  **Grinspoon‚Äôs Arguments for Studying Venus**  Grinspoon begins his argument by noting that Venus is our closest planetary neighbor. This proximity makes it the easiest planet to reach, and it also means that we can study Venus in greater detail than any other planet in our solar system. Grinspoon argues that this proximity makes Venus ‚Äúa natural first stop ?for our exploration of space.  Grinspoon also argues that Venus may once have been habitable. He cites evidence that Venus once had a thick atmosphere and a surface ocean. If this is true, then Venus could provide valuable insights into the early history of our solar system. Grinspoon argues that studying Venus could help us to understand how life began on Earth, and it could also help us to identify other planets in our solar system that may be habitable.  Finally, Grinspoon argues that Venus‚Äôs unique geology is worth studying. He notes that Venus has a very active surface, with volcanoes and tectonic plates that are constantly moving. This geology is unlike anything we see on Earth, and it could provide valuable insights into the formation of planets.  **Grinspoon‚Äôs Arguments Against Studying Venus**  Grinspoon‚Äôs arguments for studying Venus are compelling, but his argument is not without its flaws. First, Grinspoon downplays the dangers of Venus‚Äôs atmosphere and surface conditions. He acknowledges that Venus is hot and has a thick atmosphere of carbon dioxide, but he argues that these conditions are not as dangerous as they seem. Grinspoon claims that we could send robots to explore Venus without having to worry about the atmosphere or the surface conditions. However, this argument is not convincing. The atmosphere of Venus is so dense that it would crush any robot that tried to land on the planet. The surface of Venus is also so hot that it would melt any robot that tried to walk on it.  Second, Grinspoon fails to adequately address the ethical concerns that arise from sending humans to explore Venus. He acknowledges that sending humans to Venus would be dangerous, but he argues that the risks are worth taking. Grinspoon claims that the potential benefits of exploring Venus outweigh the risks. However, this argument is debatable. It is difficult to say whether the benefits of exploring Venus would outweigh the risks to human life.  **Conclusion**  Grinspoon makes a strong case for studying Venus. The planet is our closest planetary neighbor, it may once have been habitable, and it has a unique geology. However, Grinspoon‚Äôs argument is not without its flaws. He downplays the dangers of Venus‚Äôs atmosphere and surface conditions, and he fails to adequately address the ethical concerns that arise from sending humans to explore the planet. Overall, Grinspoon‚Äôs argument is persuasive, but it is not without its flaws.		1

Sure, here's my attempt at writing an essay on the pros and cons of graduating early from high school as an average 8th grade student:  Hey, so I've been thinking about graduating early from high school and I wanted to write about it. It's like, a big decision and stuff. Some people think it's a good idea, but others don't. So, let's talk about the pros and cons.  First, the pros. If you graduate early, you can get a head start on college or whatever you want to do after high school. You can take college classes or get a job or something. It's like, you're not stuck in high school forever. You can do what you want, when you want. And, you know, it looks good on college apps or whatever. Like, you're not just some lazy kid who didn't finish high school. You're like, a motivated person who's taking charge of their life.  But, there are also cons. Like, you might miss out on some stuff in high school. You might not get to hang out with your friends as much or participate in sports or clubs. And, you know, you might not be ready for college yet. It's like, you might not be mature enough or whatever. You might have to take a gap year or something. That's not cool.  And, there's also the thing where you might not be able to get into college if you graduate early. Some colleges don't accept early graduates or something. So, you might have to find another way to get into college. That's like, stressful.  But, overall, I think the pros and cons of graduating early are pretty even. It's like, it's a big decision and you should think about it carefully. Some people might think it's a good idea, but others might not. It's like, you have to decide what's best for you. The National Safety Council reports that cell phone use while driving leads one point six million crashes each year. Nearly 390,000 injuries occur each year from texting and driving. Texting while driving is something that people have done in the past, they are doing it today, and are still going to do it in the future. No matter how people are injured or have lost their lives to this people are still going to do it. Some of the main reasons that you should not text while driving is because; you can cause serious accidents that way, you are more likely to be blamed for causing the accident and it is illegal to be on the phone in some states.  According to a new study talking on the phone is hugely dangerous even if you are on hands free. There are thousands of people who get into accidents everyday because they were not paying attention to the road. They were to busy looking down at their phones to notice what was going on around them. If you are paying attention to what you are doing you can only injure yourself but you can also injure another person as well.  Most likely if you are texting while driving and end up getting into an accident then you are most likely to get blamed than the other person. There is a high chance of it being your fault because you were not paying attention to the road. Yow will also probably get charged by your insurance company and have to pay more if the other person decides to file a lawsuit against you. Being distracted for even one minute can change a whole lot and make a big difference. This causes the students at the schools that cannnot afford it to have a disadvantage. Online classes do not normally provide the materials needed for labs. While some labs you can do with materials at home, some require more dangerous materials like an open flame, sharp objects, or dangerous chemicals. Even if students can do the lab at home teachers are usually there to help or explain how the lab relates to the subject students are learning.  In the end I do not think online classes are that beneficial for students. Also, many years ago, there are speculations that Venus was probably full of oceans and could suport many different types of life, just as Earth was too. While distance learning offers flexibility and convenience, I believe students would benefit more from attending traditional in-person classes. There are a few key reasons for this.  First, learning from home could negatively impact students' social development and mental well-being. Part of the school experience is socializing and interacting with peers. At home, students may feel isolated without in-person interactions during breaks and after school. The social aspects of school are important for developing social skills and helping to prevent loneliness or depression.   Second, it can be difficult for students to stay focused and motivated while learning from home. There are many distractions at home like TV, phones, video games and chores that may tempt students. It requires strong self-discipline to avoid distractions and stick to an at-home schedule. Younger students especially may struggle without the structured environment of a classroom.  Third, online classes lack the hands-on learning experiences that in-person classes provide. Some subjects like lab sciences, arts, sports and trades benefit greatly from practical demonstrations and activities that simply cannot be replicated remotely. The experiential nature of these classes enhances understanding and retention of the material. It also allows students to get help from and ask questions to their teachers in real-time.  While distance learning offers flexibility, I believe the social and educational benefits of traditional in-person classes outweigh this convenience. Students' well-being and development are best supported through direct engagement and teaching within a structured school environment. Therefore, attending physical classes at school would be more beneficial for students than distance learning from home.		1

Cars are an integral part of many peoples lives around the world: they provede transportation to work and home, they cater to social lives, and for some they even provede a home.  However, it's becoming a trend to limit car usage, particularly in Europe. Residents in Vauban, Germany have given up cars almost completely, with the exception of a 40,000 parking garage fee that over half of the residents have elected not to use.  While it may make getting places harder, the effects of cutting down on car usage are mostly good ones.  First and foremost on this list is global warming. In Europe, cars produce around twelve percent of greenhouse emissions, while in the US, the number can be as high as fifty percent in cities. This is not good. Global warming is destroying the ice caps and the ozone layer of Earth, leading to a temperature increase that is damaging many environments around the world. This, in addition to pollution released by cars and the oil industry, could permanently cripple our planet. Any way that we can cut the effects of global warming should be implemented.  Secondly, crowded cities benefit in many ways from a lessening of driving. Some cities, like Paris, have already had to enact a partial ban on driving due to a heavy smog layer. Other cities, like Beijing, is even more polluted, and cities in this country suffer as well. If less people drove, the air would be clearer, as was the case in Paris.  Also, there is less crowding when less people are driving. Anyone who has driven through or lived in a large city knows just how bad congestion and traffic jams can be. Less driving would mean less congestion, making it easier for people to get to work, school, or other locations on time. When Paris enacted its driving ban of those with evennumbered licence plates, congestion went down sixty percent.  Finally, using an alternative to cars can save money.		0

**Driverless Cars: A Boon or a Bane?**  Driverless cars have the potential to revolutionize transportation, but there are also significant risks to consider. In this essay, I will argue that the benefits of driverless cars outweigh the risks.  **Benefits of Driverless Cars**  There are a number of benefits to be gained from the development of driverless cars. First, driverless cars would eliminate the human factor in driving, which is responsible for a significant number of traffic accidents. According to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA), over 3 million people are injured and 30,000 people are killed in car accidents each year in the United States. Driverless cars could help to reduce these numbers by making roads safer.  Second, driverless cars would make travel more convenient. Drivers would no longer have to worry about the stress of driving, such as dealing with traffic, finding parking, or being tired behind the wheel. They could simply sit back and relax while their car took them to their destination. This would free up people's time and allow them to do other things, such as work, read, or socialize.  Third, driverless cars could help to reduce pollution. According to the EPA, transportation is the largest source of greenhouse gas emissions in the United States. Driverless cars could help to reduce emissions by driving more efficiently and avoiding traffic congestion.  **Risks of Driverless Cars**  There are also some risks associated with the development of driverless cars. One risk is that driverless cars could be hacked. If a hacker were able to gain control of a driverless car, they could potentially cause it to crash or to drive in a dangerous manner. This could pose a significant safety risk.  Another risk is that driverless cars could lead to job losses. As driverless cars become more common, there will be less need for human drivers. This could lead to job losses in the transportation industry.  **Conclusion**  In conclusion, the benefits of driverless cars outweigh the risks. Driverless cars have the potential to make roads safer, travel more convenient, and reduce pollution. However, there are also some risks associated with the development of driverless cars, such as the potential for hacking and job losses. It is important to weigh the benefits and risks carefully before making a decision about whether or not to support the development of driverless cars.		1
 Driverless cars are a topic that has been generating a lot of buzz in recent years. These fully autonomous vehicles have the potential to revolutionize the way we travel and improve road safety. In this essay, we will explore the benefits and challenges of driverless cars, and what the future might hold for this emerging technology.  One of the most significant benefits of driverless cars is the potential to greatly reduce the number of accidents on the road. Human error is a leading cause of traffic accidents, and autonomous vehicles have the potential to eliminate this factor entirely. With advanced sensors, cameras, and artificial intelligence, driverless cars can detect and respond to potential hazards on the road in real-time, preventing accidents before they even occur.  Another benefit of driverless cars is increased mobility for those who are unable to drive. This includes the elderly, people with disabilities, and others who may not have access to a driver's license. Driverless cars could provide these individuals with the independence and freedom to travel when and where they choose.  However, there are also challenges associated with driverless cars. One of the biggest challenges is cost. Autonomous vehicles are currently very expensive to produce, and this cost is likely to be passed on to consumers. This could make driverless cars less accessible to the general public.  Another challenge is the potential for job losses. As driverless cars become more widespread, there may be a decrease in demand for jobs such as taxi drivers, truck drivers, and delivery drivers. This could have a significant impact on the economy, and it is important to consider the potential consequences of this shift in the job market.  In conclusion, driverless cars have the potential to greatly improve road safety and increase mobility for those who are unable to drive. However, there are also challenges associated with this emerging technology, including cost and potential job losses. As we move forward, it will be important to carefully consider the benefits and challenges of driverless cars, and to develop policies that maximize the benefits while minimizing the risks. Overall, the future of driverless cars is exciting, and it will be interesting to see how this technology continues to develop in the coming years.		1
What is summer to you? Warm air, blistering sun, hot sandy beaches, cool ocean water, hanging out with friends, freedom, no responsibilities? Or is it the dreadful summer assignment you are forced to do by your calculus teacher? Summer is a time to have fun and enjoy a needed break from the monotonous and boring school routine, not a time to be doing more schoolwork for the next year. It is understandable, summer is too long to go without doing at least a little bit of learning, however, wouldn't it be much more bearable to do a summer project on something you actually want to learn about? Summer projects should be student-designed because they should be able to pursue something they enjoy, teachers won't be available for help, and more students would complete the assignment on time.  Many students in this world don't find a need for what they learn in high school when they find a job in the real world. Generally, many students struggle to find something they enjoy in a class in high school, but are still forced to take them, resulting in little time to explore what they are really passionate about. So why should students be forced to do boring projects on for classes they don't actually like over the summer, when they are supposed to be given a break to relax from school and have fun? It would be much more beneficial and enjoyable for students to explore their interests during a time they aren't stressed with other schoolwork. Giving the students the opportunity to choose what they work on for their summer assignment could help immensely with steering students towards the right career path by having them choose something that they personally find interesting.  Summer is also a time for the teachers to be given a break from school. During the school year, many teachers are working the five days during the week at the school, then grading over the weekends on their own time for no extra pay. Teachers embrace the long break and release of stress that comes with the hot air of summer just as much as the students do, and the last thing on their minds is the summer assignments they gave to all of their students. With many projects, especially ones as big as the ones given out for summer assignments, students need the support of their teachers to fully understand what they have to do, and with teachers out of action for the summer, they will have trouble understanding what is being assigned to them and may struggle completing the project. If students were able to choose what their project could be on, they would choose something that they understand better and wouldn't need the help and support of their teachers.  Although summer assignments are usually required and meant to be worked on over the course of the summer, many students push it off until the last week or just don't complete it at all because of how much they really dread doing the work. Many teenagers in general will do the things they enjoy until they absolutely have to do the things they don't want to do. If the summer project is on something they don't want to do, a large majority of students would push it off until late August to start, which defeats the purpose of having a summer assignment at all. If students were able to choose what they wanted to work on for their summer projects, they would be more encouraged and motivated to complete the assignment on time and work on it throughout the summer rather than waiting until the last minute.  Summer should be a period that students and teachers alike should look forward to as a time to relax and be free from the constant stresses of school. They should enjoy themselves in whichever way suits them during this time and should be doing the things they want to do, not what they are forced to do. By letting the students choose to focus on the things they enjoy, summer can be what everybody wants it to be, fun for everyone.		0
Productivity versus Idleness: A Comparative Analysis  Introduction  Productivity and idleness are two contrasting ways of life that can have significant impacts on a person's life and career opportunities. While productivity is often associated with success and recognition, idleness can lead to a lack of fulfillment and missed opportunities. In this essay, I will explore the benefits and drawbacks of both productivity and idleness, examine examples of successful people who have worked hard to gain recognition, and analyze the effects of idleness on a person's life and career opportunities.  Benefits of Productivity  Productivity is the state of being highly efficient and productive in one's work. It is often associated with success and recognition, as it allows individuals to accomplish more in less time. Productivity can lead to increased job satisfaction, higher salaries, and better career opportunities. For example, individuals who are productive and efficient in their work are often seen as valuable assets to their employers and are more likely to be promoted or given additional responsibilities.  Drawbacks of Idleness  Idleness, on the other hand, is the state of being unproductive and inactive. It can lead to a lack of fulfillment and missed opportunities. Idleness can also have negative impacts on a person's mental and physical health. For example, individuals who spend too much time sitting and not engaging in physical activity are at an increased risk of obesity, heart disease, and other health issues. Additionally, idleness can lead to feelings of boredom and dissatisfaction, which can negatively impact a person's overall well-being.  Examples of Successful People  There are many successful people who have worked hard to gain recognition. For example, Oprah Winfrey, one of the most successful media personalities of all time, rose from a poverty-stricken childhood to become a household name. Her success was due in large part to her hard work, determination, and productivity. Similarly, Elon Musk, the CEO of Tesla and SpaceX, has achieved incredible success through his hard work and dedication to his projects. Both Winfrey and Musk are examples of individuals who have worked hard to achieve success and recognition.  Effects of Idleness  Idleness can have significant negative effects on a person's life and career opportunities.		1

The Development of Driverless Cars   Driverless cars promise both benefits and risks for the future of transportation. While autonomous vehicles could help reduce traffic accidents and increase mobility, developing this new technology also presents serious safety and ethical concerns that must be addressed. On balance, I believe policymakers should support research into driverless cars but proceed cautiously before widespread adoption.  One of the primary benefits cited in the article is that driverless cars could reduce traffic accidents caused by human error. Without the risks of drunk, distracted or drowsy driving, autonomous vehicles may lower collision rates significantly. This safety advantage is compelling, as car accidents currently cause tens of thousands of deaths each year in many countries. By removing the human element of poor judgement from driving decisions, driverless vehicles could help curb these casualties.   However, the article also notes serious technical and ethical issues still to be resolved. Autonomous systems may struggle with unexpected hazards like construction zones or malfunctioning traffic lights. Software or sensors could malfunction in ways that cause accidents, as this technology is still in development. More concerning are ‚Äúedge cases ?where a computer must choose between outcomes like hitting a pedestrian or swerving into oncoming traffic‚Äîlife-or-death scenarios not easily programmed. Public fears over loss of control or hackable systems could also hamper acceptance and regulation.  While driverless cars show promise for improving transportation, the issues above indicate this technology requires further progress to become truly safe and socially beneficial on a mass scale. Rather than an outright ban or unrestricted adoption, policymakers should support continued research and pilots studies while enacting guidelines to protect users during development. With careful testing and standards that prioritize safety above all else, many of the risks identified in the article could be mitigated over time. Once autonomous vehicles can pass stringent, real-world certification without undue hazards, shifting policy to permit limited consumer use may become reasonable. Overall, a balanced approach seems wisest for responsibly guiding this influential new technology.  In conclusion, while driverless cars offer potential benefits, the challenges raised in developing autonomous vehicles warrant moderate policies that encourage research but proceed deliberately to resolve safety and ethical concerns before widespread adoption. Continued improvements and safeguards seem necessary to ensure this transformative technology ultimately provides more benefits than risks for public road users in the future.		1

Overall,¬†By schools allowing summer projects to be student designed, more will get done while not feeling forced to do it. Also this will allow the students to learn a lot more by being interested in the topic that they have chosen themselves. Then the teachers won't have to worry about people not turning it in or doing it last minute. This is why schools should make summer assignments student designed, based on the fact that it has more benefits to the teachers and the students.		0

 First impressions are often seen as set in stone, with little room for change. However, I believe that this is a misconception. While first impressions can be difficult to alter, they are not impossible to change. In fact, with effort and awareness, individuals can work to overcome negative first impressions and form more positive ones.  One of the reasons why first impressions can be difficult to change is because they are often based on superficial factors. For example, someone may make a negative first impression based on a person's appearance, body language, or accent. However, these factors may not accurately reflect a person's true character or personality. By recognizing that first impressions are often based on superficial factors, individuals can work to overcome negative first impressions by getting to know the person on a deeper level.  Additionally, first impressions can be influenced by a person's own biases and prejudices. For example, someone may make a negative first impression of someone based on their race or ethnicity, without even realizing it. By becoming aware of their own biases and working to overcome them, individuals can work to form more positive first impressions.  In my experience, I have seen first impressions change over time. For example, when I first met someone at a party, I may have formed a negative first impression based on their appearance or behavior. However, as I got to know them better, I may have discovered that they were actually very kind and caring individuals. By recognizing that first impressions can change over time, individuals can work to overcome negative first impressions and form more positive ones.  In conclusion, while first impressions can be difficult to change, they are not impossible. By recognizing that first impressions are often based on superficial factors and can be influenced by biases and prejudices, individuals can work to overcome negative first impressions and form more positive ones. With effort and awareness, individuals can create a more positive and inclusive environment for themselves and others.		1
Gathering multiple opinions helps people make better choices by giving them multiple viewpoints. These new viewpoints can give them various new way to approach the decision. By having multiple ways to approach the problem, you can choose the best one and make the best decision.  Asking someone for advice can make you realize an option that you haven't thought of yet. Sometimes you think that you can only choose one of two or three options. However, when you ask someone else for advice, they might notice an option that you hadn't noticed that's even better. One time I had a track meet on my friends birthday. I wanted to go to his birthday party and celebrate with him, but my team really needed me to run the mile event because I had the fastest mile time out of the team. I asked my coach if it would be okay if I missed the meet, then he told me that I could just run the mile and then leave afterward. I hadn't thought of that because usually, everyone runs all the events just to give each team a better chance at the fastest time. So decided to leave early for my friend's party. I ended up¬†winning the mile event, and then having a great time at my friend's party. Another reason to gather different viewpoints is other people might view the decision in a different way. By gaining a different viewpoint of the decision, you could notice new pros and cons that you hadn't thought of for each option. Four years later I'm still enjoying Boy Scouts, I've gone on dozens of camping trips, and made some of my best friends. Asking my great uncle for advice was really helpful in that situation.  Asking people for advice is very important, because hearing other viewpoints can give us a new way of thinking about the decision we have to make. The next time you have to make an important choice, try asking people you trust for advice.		0

 Using Facial Action Coding System technology to read the emotional expressions of students in a classroom could potentially provide some benefits, but it also raises significant privacy concerns that make its overall value questionable.   On one hand, this technology may help teachers gain insights into how their students are responding to lessons on an individual level. By detecting if students appear bored, confused, or engaged as class is ongoing, teachers could potentially make adjustments to improve instruction. This level of emotion detection could help ensure more students understand content and stay motivated to learn. The technology may also flag if a particular student seems distressed, allowing a teacher to check in on their wellbeing.  However, continuously monitoring students' facial expressions without their consent crosses an ethical line. Classrooms are meant to be safe, inclusive environments for learning, not testing grounds for experimental technologies. Students should feel free to naturally express a range of emotions‚Äîincluding frustration with difficult concepts‚Äîwithout being subjected to computerized emotion surveillance. Even if data is supposedly anonymous, many students could still feel self-conscious under such monitoring, undermining their comfort at school.   There are also concerns about accuracy and potential misinterpretation of data. Facial expression analysis is an imperfect science, so computers meant to detect emotions may misclassify students' responses. Teachers relying on this flawed data risk making incorrect assumptions about how students are processing lessons. Students could end up being unfairly judged or perceived in a way that does not truly reflect their experiences in class.   Overall, while emotion detection technology hints at possible benefits, its application in classrooms raises serious problems related to student privacy, consent, and data reliability that are not easily solved. Unless such issues can be addressed through transparent safeguards that prioritize student well-being over experimental uses of technology, this surveillance threatens more harm than good to the learning environment. While the goals of insight into teaching and learning are worthwhile, this particular approach appears premature and potentially damaging without major changes.		1
 The question of whether we choose our own character traits or if they are formed by influences beyond our control is a complex one. On the one hand, some people believe that our character is largely determined by our upbringing, genetics, and life experiences. On the other hand, others argue that we have the power to shape our own character through our choices and actions. In my opinion, I believe that we need to choose our own character traits.  Firstly, when we choose our own character, we are able to align our actions with our values and beliefs. This allows us to live a life that is authentic and meaningful to us. For example, if we choose to be honest and trustworthy, we will be able to build strong relationships with others and earn their respect. On the other hand, if we choose to be dishonest or deceitful, we may damage our relationships and harm others.  Secondly, when we choose our own character, we are able to take responsibility for our actions and the consequences that come with them. This allows us to learn from our mistakes and grow as individuals. For example, if we choose to be responsible and accountable, we will be able to take ownership of our actions and learn from them. On the other hand, if we choose to blame others or shift responsibility, we may not learn from our mistakes and may repeat them in the future.  Finally, when we choose our own character, we are able to live a life that is fulfilling and satisfying. This allows us to achieve our goals and aspirations. For example, if we choose to pursue our passions and interests, we will be able to live a life that is meaningful and fulfilling. On the other hand, if we choose to live a life that is not aligned with our values and beliefs, we may feel unfulfilled and unsatisfied.  In conclusion, I believe that we need to choose our own character traits in order to live a life that is authentic, meaningful, and fulfilling. By aligning our actions with our values and beliefs, taking responsibility for our actions, and pursuing our passions and interests, we can shape our own character and live a life that is truly ours.		1

Dear Senator,   I am writing to share my perspective on whether the United States should keep the current Electoral College system or change to a popular vote for electing the President. After reviewing arguments on both sides of this issue, I believe the Electoral College should be maintained.  One advantage of the Electoral College is that it encourages candidates to build broader coalitions and campaign in a wider array of states. If we moved to a popular vote, candidates would likely focus all of their attention on highly populated urban areas. This could disenfranchise voters in rural states. The Electoral College system gives citizens in smaller states a louder voice and encourages candidates to consider the needs of all regions of the country.   Some argue this is unfair and that the candidate with the most total votes nationwide should win. However, switching to a popular vote could actually discourage voter turnout. Citizens in states that heavily favor one party may feel their votes do not really matter or change the outcome. The Electoral College gives more voters in more states a feeling that their votes are meaningful and could influence the election. It helps motivate high voter participation.  It is also worth considering that the Founding Fathers established the Electoral College system as a compromise between election by Congress and nationwide popular vote. It was a deliberate decision based on concerns about direct democracy and mob rule. While the current system may not be perfect, changing it could have unintended consequences and weaken the federal character of the presidential election process. On balance, maintaining the Electoral College appears to best uphold bipartisan values of equality, participation and political stability.  In conclusion, I believe the advantages of the current Electoral College system outweigh arguments for switching to a popular vote. It has generally worked well for over two centuries and helps ensure all citizens have a meaningful say in choosing the nation's president. I hope you will support keeping the Electoral College as we have known it. Please let me know if you have any other questions.  Sincerely, [Your name]		1

  Dear [State Senator],  I am writing to express my opinion on the Electoral College system used to elect the President of the United States. After reading and analyzing various sources, including "Does the Electoral College Work?" by the Office of the Federal Register, "The Indefensible Electoral College" by Bradford Plumer, and "In Defense of the Electoral College: Five Reasons to Keep Our Despised Method of Choosing the President" by Judge Richard A. Posner, I have come to the conclusion that the Electoral College is a fair and effective system for electing the President.  One of the main arguments in favor of the Electoral College is that it ensures a clear winner in the presidential election. Unlike a popular vote system, where a candidate could win an election with a plurality of votes but still lose the presidency, the Electoral College requires a candidate to receive a majority of votes (270 out of 538) to win the presidency. This helps to prevent political polarization and guarantees that the President will have the support of a broad coalition of states. As Judge Posner argues, "a victory by the same margin in Wyoming would net the winner only 3 electoral votes. So, other things being equal, a large state gets more attention from presidential candidates in a campaign than a small state does" (Posner). This helps to ensure that smaller states have a voice in the election process.  Another benefit of the Electoral College is that it encourages candidates to campaign across the country, rather than just focusing on heavily populated areas. As Bradford Plumer argues, "it is highly unlikely that a candidate will win the presidency without winning the majority of the electoral votes" (Plumer). This means that candidates must appeal to voters in a wide		1

World war II had now ended and many countries were left destroyed, to help the countries recover from war they will need things such as food, animals, and many other things. The " Seagoing Cowboys" were hired to take care of the horses, young cows, and mules that were shipped over seas. In August 1945, they got orders to report to New Orleans. Luke and his friend arrived on August 14th, the same day the Pacific war ended. There was 335 horses to take care of. Before arriving in Greece Luke turned 18, which means that he is now eligable to be drafted for the military service. In 1947 Luke had made nine trips, more than any seagoing cowboy. Luke ended up touring many places around the world. Luke was doing his job chcking on the animals, but this time was different it was raining, Luke accidentally slid down a ladder and almost fell into the deep dark ocean but a piece of metal stopped him fromm falling. Luke was lucky to be alive but he still was injured with some cracked ribs. Although it wasn't always fun, Luke found things to do like baseball, volleyball, tennis, and many more things.   Dear [State Senator's Name],  I am writing to express my opinion on the Electoral College system used to elect the President of the United States. As a concerned citizen and student, I believe that the Electoral College is an outdated and unfair system that should be abolished in favor of a direct popular vote.  One of the main arguments in favor of the Electoral College is that it ensures a more representative election by giving more weight to votes from swing states. However, as Bradford Plumer argues in his article "The Indefensible Electoral College," this system can lead to a situation where a candidate wins the presidency without receiving the most popular votes. This happened in the 2000 election when Al Gore received more individual votes than George W. Bush nationwide, but Bush won the election due to the Electoral College system. This is an unfair scenario that undermines the democratic principles of the United States.  Another argument against the Electoral College is that it disproportionately represents the interests of smaller states. As Judge Richard A. Posner notes in his article "In Defense of the Electoral College," the winner-take-all method of awarding electoral votes induces candidates to focus their campaign efforts on toss-up states, which are often larger states. This means that voters in smaller states have less influence on the election outcome, which is unfair and undemocratic.  Furthermore, the Electoral College system can lead to a tie in the Electoral College, which would result in the House of Representatives choosing the president. As Posner argues, this would be a catastrophic scenario that would undermine the democratic process.  On the other hand, some argue that the Electoral College ensures that a presidential candidate must		1

[Your Name] [Your Address] [City, State, ZIP] [Email Address] [Phone Number] [Date]  [Senator's Name] [Address] [City, State, ZIP]  Dear Senator [Senator's Last Name],  I am writing to express my support for keeping the Electoral College in place for the election of the President of the United States. While many argue for a shift towards a popular vote system, I believe that the Electoral College provides several important benefits that should be considered.  First and foremost, the Electoral College ensures a certainty of outcome. By awarding electoral votes on a winner-take-all basis, the winning candidate's share of the Electoral College typically exceeds their share of the popular vote. This minimizes the likelihood of disputed election results, as seen in the 2000 election between Al Gore and George W. Bush. The Electoral College provides a clear and decisive path to victory, which is crucial for maintaining a stable democracy.  Additionally, the Electoral College promotes representation for all regions of the country. No single region has enough electoral votes to elect a president, meaning that candidates must have trans-regional appeal to win the presidency. This prevents candidates from solely focusing on regions where they have the most support, ensuring that the president will have broad-based support and take into account the interests of all Americans. It also prevents candidates from ignoring states with smaller populations, as the winner-take-all method of awarding electoral votes gives even small states some weight in the election.  The Electoral College also encourages candidates to campaign in swing states, where the outcome of the election is less certain. This means that voters in these states, who are more likely to pay close attention to the campaign, have a greater influence on the outcome of the election. It encourages candidates to engage with voters directly and tailor their policies to address the concerns of these swing states. By doing so, the Electoral College ensures that the most thoughtful voters, who have received the most information and attention from the candidates, have a say in deciding the election.  Furthermore, the Electoral College balances the influence of large and small states in the political process. While the mal-apportionment of the Senate may give smaller states more influence, the Electoral College ensures that large states receive more attention from presidential candidates. This means that candidates must consider the concerns and interests of both large and small states, maintaining a balance of power and preventing one group from dominating the decision-making process.  Lastly, the Electoral College avoids the complications of run-off elections. When no candidate receives a majority of the popular vote, run-off elections may be necessary. The Electoral College reduces the likelihood of this scenario by invariably producing a clear winner. This streamlines the election process and allows for a smooth transition of power.  In conclusion, the Electoral College system provides several important benefits that should not be overlooked. It ensures a certainty of outcome, promotes regional representation, encourages campaigning in swing states, balances the influence of large and small states, and avoids the need for run-off elections. While there may be arguments in favor of a popular vote system, I believe that the Electoral College remains the best method for electing the President of the United States.  Thank you for considering my perspective on this issue. I trust that you will take into account the diverse viewpoints and interests of your constituents when making decisions that affect our democracy.  Sincerely,  [Your Name]		1

Dear Senator,  I am writing to you today to express my support for the Electoral College. As a high school student, I am concerned about the future of our country and believe that the Electoral College is the best way to ensure that the President represents the will of the people.  The Electoral College is a system in which each state is allocated a number of electors equal to its number of senators and representatives in Congress. These electors are chosen by the voters in each state, and they cast their votes for President on the first Monday after the second Wednesday in December. The candidate who receives a majority of the electoral votes is elected President.  The Electoral College has been in place since the founding of our country, and it has served us well for over 200 years. It prevents a few large states from dominating the election and ensures that all states have a voice in choosing the President.  One of the biggest arguments against the Electoral College is that it can lead to a President being elected who did not win the popular vote. This happened in 2016, when Donald Trump won the Electoral College despite losing the popular vote by nearly 3 million votes.  However, I believe that this is a rare occurrence and that the Electoral College is still the best way to ensure that the President represents the will of the people. In fact, a study by the University of Chicago found that the Electoral College has actually been more likely to elect the candidate who won the popular vote than the popular vote has been to elect the candidate who won the Electoral College.  Another argument against the Electoral College is that it is undemocratic. However, I believe that the Electoral College is actually more democratic than the popular vote. The popular vote is decided by a handful of states with large populations, while the Electoral College gives all states equal representation. This means that smaller states have a voice in the election, even if they have a smaller population.  I urge you to vote against any proposal to abolish the Electoral College. The Electoral College is a vital part of our democracy, and it ensures that all states have a voice in choosing the President.  Sincerely,  A Concerned High School Student		1

The first reason why i think we should take community service is because its very nice, it helps others out with some stuff and also it makes you feel better about yourself. Community service is always about being nice some of the students thinks its a waste of time, but they don't know what it is until they actually see the peoples faces when we be nice and jump out of our way to make them happy. Its amazing how one person can actually do that.  Helping out others could really be a drag sometimes but when the work is done it looks a lot better. This world would be a lot of a better place if people would just help each other with some little things. For an example: Some lady is getting very old and she needs someone to cut her grass every week. Someone could be so nice enough and just go cut the grass for free and see how she's doing. Helping others and being nice is all in the same concept. We all need to just do it maybe for a week. Trust me if people would realize how much we can help in this world I think we all could do it !  Community service is not only good for them its also good for yourself. Doesn't everyone love the feeling that your a hero ?
