Meat is a major part of many people's diets. However, there is a growing movement that suggests reducing the amount of meat that we consume. These people argue that eating meat is bad for the environment and for our health. In this essay, I will argue against adopting a vegetarian or vegan diet.  Firstly, meat is an important source of protein, which is necessary for the growth and repair of our bodies. Without meat, it is difficult to get enough protein in our diets. This is especially important for young people, who need protein to support their growth and development. Additionally, meat is a convenient and accessible source of protein, making it a practical choice for many people.  Secondly, the production of meat is not as harmful to the environment as some people suggest. Yes, it is true that the livestock industry produces greenhouse gas emissions, but these can be reduced through sustainable farming practices. In fact, some studies have shown that grass-fed beef can actually be better for the environment than plant-based alternatives. Furthermore, the demand for meat is not going away anytime soon, so it is important to find ways to produce it sustainably.  Thirdly, there are many delicious and nutritious ways to include meat in our diets. For example, a juicy steak or a hearty bowl of beef stew are both tasty and nutritious options. Meat can also be incorporated into a variety of dishes, such as stir-fries, curries, and pasta sauces. This means that there are plenty of ways to include meat in our diets without sacrificing flavor or nutrition.  Finally, adopting a vegetarian or vegan diet can be difficult and expensive. Many plant-based alternatives to meat are costly, and it can be challenging to ensure that you are getting all the nutrients that your body needs. This is especially true for people with busy schedules or limited access to healthy food options.  In conclusion, while there are some valid concerns about the environmental and health impacts of meat consumption, I believe that adopting a vegetarian or vegan diet is not the best solution. Instead, we should focus on finding sustainable ways to produce meat and incorporating it into our diets in a responsible and nutritious way. This will allow us to enjoy the benefits of meat while also doing our part to protect the environment and our health.		1

 Yes, the electoral college works as intended. The system, established by the framers of the United States Constitution, was designed to give each state a proportional role in the selection of the president. It ensures that small states, with their limited resources and interests, have a fair say in the election.   To argue that the electoral college is flawed, one must consider the potential for undue influence from campaign funds, the distortion of the election by voter fraud, and the lack of a direct election. However, the electoral college mitigates these potential issues and ensures a fair and balanced decision.  First, the electoral college prevents campaigns from being won solely by winning in large states. Candidates must work to win over voters in smaller states, where resources may be limited and attitudes diverse. This ensures a more representative selection of the president.  Second, voter fraud is still a prevalent issue and a direct election could be susceptible to it. The electoral college, with its checks and balances, minimizes the potential impact of fraud and ensures a more reliable outcome.  Finally, the electoral college ensures a balanced decision. By giving equal representation to each state, it ensures that the selection of the president is not skewed by the majority of the population. If a presidential candidate were to win a popular vote, but lose the electoral vote, the system would still ensure a balanced outcome, and the candidate who won over more voters would be chosen as president.  In conclusion, the electoral college works as intended by ensuring a fair and balanced selection of the president. It gives each state a proportional role in the election and minimizes the impact of campaign funds, voter fraud, and the influence of the majority of the population. The system will continue to work effectively as long as it is respected and implemented properly.		1

As a student currently enrolled in a multitude of AP or DE classes, I can agree that distance learning may be a good source for students that can't attend school for whatever reason. With distance learning students will be able to better their education when they are sick and need to take leave, need a bit of extra help outside of the classroom, and finally for students that have mental disorders or are diseases that limit their ability to go out.  In many cases, espicially in high school, students will avoid missing school when they are sick becasue the benefit of staying home to heal from sickness does not exceed the cost of missing school. Due to the excessive amounts of work, the majority of students prefer to tough it out and go to school. If distance learning was an option it would limit the exposure of sick individuals to the general school population. With distance learning students would then be able to watch videos or online conference with their teachers so that they don't miss anything important during class.  Another benefit that distance learning may have is the ability for students to gain extra help. For many students the learning pace during school is too fast and hard to keep up with, but with the use of distance learning students would be able to watch videos at home or conference privately with their teachers. Along with a fast learning pace, some students may feel embaressed or shy during class and don't like asking questions. Through distance learning students can access the extra help they need by opening there laptop to watch a video compared to spending excess amounts of money and time on a tutor. Today in society more than a fourth of the population suffers from some sort of mental or physical disorder which limits the way they preform during school. For students that have physcial disabilities or diseases and can't leave there home or the hospital, they would still be able to learn like a "normal" student in a classroom setting.¬†With the use of distance learning these students would be able to watch videos and conference with teachers to help learn and improve their education. Most students and staff have access to a computer or some sort of technology that will provide them the oppertunity to watch videos online or video conference with a teacher.  The cowboy who rode the waves refers to the famous surfer, Duke Kahanamoku. Born in Hawaii, Duke was not your typical cowboy. In fact, he was an Olympic swimmer and the first person of Hawaiian descent to win a gold medal at the games. However, he was also a skilled surfer and became famous for his ability to ride the waves with ease and precision.  Duke was not like other surfers of his time. He was not interested in the flashy tricks and maneuvers that were popular with other surfers. Instead, he focused on mastering the basics of surfing. He spent countless hours in the water, studying the tides, the waves, and the currents. He learned to read the ocean like a book, able to predict the behavior of the waves and adjust his technique accordingly.  Over time, Duke's skills grew, and he became one of the most respected surfers in the world. He won numerous surfing competitions and appeared in many movies and TV shows, showcasing his talent to audiences around the world. He was known for his humility, his kindness, and his love of the ocean.  But there was more to Duke than his surfing skills. He was also an accomplished swimmer, earning him the nickname "The Duke of Waikiki." He won two gold medals at the 1912 Stockholm Olympics in the 100-meter and 400-meter freestyle events, becoming the first person of Hawaiian descent to win a gold medal.  Duke's legacy continues to inspire surfers and ocean enthusiasts around the world. He showed us that with hard work, dedication, and a deep love for the ocean, anything is possible. He was a true cowboy, riding the waves with the same grace, skill, and determination as he swam through the water. His legacy will continue to live on, inspiring generations to come.		1

But the idea of not letting my peers take extra-curricular classes is a drastic change in the policy that we have become accustomed to.  Some students take these activities as motivation to do better in school, or to keep them out of trouble. That is only one example.  Every student has a story, a background. Sometimes, there is a glue to holding their life together, whether it be band, glee club, or football. Every student deserves a chance to have fun and do what interests them, and if it didn't interest them, they wouldn't show up to these activities.  Sir, I implore you to think twice on this possible change. Without these activities, the students might come to a point to where they don't respect you as much as they could. Instead, you could see what the students are struggling with, and get teachers to help them in there areas that are needing assistance. Maybe even instead of changing the policy, just add another after-school activity set on helping people in need. To help raise the C average to a B. The advantages of limiting car usage are numerous and well-documented, including:  * Reduced air pollution: Cars are a major source of air pollution, which can cause a variety of health problems, including asthma, heart disease, and cancer. Limiting car usage can help to improve air quality and reduce the risk of these health problems. * Reduced traffic congestion: Traffic congestion is a major problem in many cities, causing delays and frustration for drivers. Limiting car usage can help to reduce traffic congestion and make it easier for people to get around. * Increased physical activity: Walking and biking are great forms of exercise, which can help to improve people's health. Limiting car usage can encourage people to walk or bike more often, which can lead to a healthier population. * Reduced fuel consumption: Cars are a major consumer of fossil fuels, which contribute to climate change. Limiting car usage can help to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and protect the environment. * Increased community cohesion: When people walk or bike instead of driving, they have more opportunities to interact with their neighbors. This can help to build stronger communities and make people feel more connected to their surroundings.  In addition to these advantages, limiting car usage can also save people money. The average American spends over $9,000 per year on car ownership, including the cost of the car itself, gas, insurance, and maintenance. Limiting car usage can help people to save this money and use it for other things.  Of course, there are also some challenges associated with limiting car usage. One challenge is that it can be difficult to change people's habits. Many people are used to driving everywhere, and it can be difficult for them to adjust to walking or biking instead. Another challenge is that some places are not well-designed for walking or biking. In order to encourage people to walk or bike, communities need to make sure that there are safe and convenient places to do so.  Despite the challenges, limiting car usage is a worthwhile goal. The advantages of doing so are numerous, and the challenges can be overcome. By making a conscious effort to limit our car usage, we can make a positive impact on our health, our communities, and the environment.		1
Seven hours per day for five days a week and some students have activities to do after school, along with that students have mountain high piles of homework nightly. Some couldn't fathom the amount of stress that students are under today. For those reasons, a principal adding a mandatory extracurricular activity is understandable, yet unrealistic.  Seven hours of school for five days is a very large amount of time spent on academics, but some students also do sports, tutoring, or some other activity after school in the very minimal time they have. Students who participate in sports may have been doing it all their life, so adding an extracurricular could possibly affect their sports schedule. Other students may be struggling with an aspect of school and they go to tutoring for that reason. Adding an extracurricular could interfere with the help they need to succeed.  Starting from age seven students are asked to do homework. When students are seven and in 1st grade they may not have a large amount of homework; however, when students are in high school the quantity will only grow. While some homework may not take much time for one student, another student may struggle with the assignment. For those reasons, it would be hard to expect much of a student if they also have to participate in an extracurricular. Whether that stress comes from bullying, home life, school work, mental health, or high expectations, stress is unsettling high in students of all ages. Middle school student worry about the transition to high school, and high school¬†students¬†worry about their transition to college. All students worry, even if those worries are irrational, they are still stressed. That is why adding an extracurricular could be too much to ask of students.  Overall, extracurricular activities¬†being mandatory sounds wonderful and has many pros as well, but when people look closer they realize that it would end up as a train wreck. Extracurricular¬†activities should stay optional for those students who have the time and the energy to do their absolute best.		0
Summer break is a time of year that many people look forward to. It's a time when students and teachers can take a break from the rigors of school and recharge their batteries. However, there are many different opinions about the importance of summer break compared to graduating early and spending time with family. In this essay, I will compare the importance of these three things and outline the pros and cons of each.  The first thing to consider is the importance of graduating early. There are many benefits to graduating early, such as being able to start your career sooner and potentially earning more money. Additionally, graduating early can give you a sense of accomplishment and pride in your achievements. However, there are also some cons to graduating early. For example, you may not have had the same opportunities to learn and grow as you would have if you had taken a more traditional four-year college path. Additionally, graduating early can be stressful, as you may feel like you have to rush to complete all of your coursework and graduate on time.  The second thing to consider is the importance of spending time with family. Spending time with family is important because it allows you to reconnect and bond with the people who are most important to you. It's a time when you can relax and enjoy each other's company without the stress of school and work. Additionally, spending time with family can be a great way to learn new skills and gain valuable life experiences. However, there are also some cons to spending too much time with family. For example, you may feel like you're missing out on other opportunities, such as traveling or pursuing your passions.  The third thing to consider is the importance of summer break. Summer break is a time when students and teachers can take a break from the rigors of school and recharge their batteries. It's a time when you can relax and enjoy the sunshine, spend time with friends, and pursue your hobbies. Additionally, summer break can be a great time to take courses and graduate early if you wish to. However, there are also some cons to summer break. For example, you may feel like you're missing out on the opportunity to learn and grow if you don't take advantage of the summer to pursue your passions. Additionally, summer break can be expensive, as you may need to pay for travel, housing, and other expenses		1

Extending the school day two hours in a four-day school week is a topic that has been widely debated in recent years. While some argue that this would provide students with more opportunities to learn and grow, others believe that it would have negative consequences on their academic performance and well-being. In this essay, I will analyze the potential benefits and disadvantages of this proposed change.  On the one hand, extending the school day two hours in a four-day school week would provide students with more time to learn and engage in extracurricular activities. This would allow them to delve deeper into their academic interests and pursue their passions. Additionally, it would provide them with more opportunities to interact with their peers and teachers, which would improve their social and emotional development.  Furthermore, this change would also benefit students who struggle academically. By providing them with more time to learn and practice, they would be better equipped to succeed in their classes. This would ultimately lead to better academic performance and a higher likelihood of graduation.  On the other hand, extending the school day two hours in a four-day school week would also have its drawbacks. Firstly, it would require students to attend school for a longer period of time, which could lead to increased stress and burnout. This could negatively impact their mental and physical health, as well as their academic performance.  Additionally, this change would also require teachers to work longer hours, which could lead to increased workload and burnout. This could ultimately lead to a decrease in the quality of education provided to students.  In conclusion, extending the school day two hours in a four-day school week has both potential benefits and disadvantages. While it would provide students with more time to learn and grow, it could also lead to increased stress and burnout. Ultimately, the decision to implement this change should be based on a careful analysis of its potential impact on students and teachers.		1

 The concept of car-free cities has gained significant traction in recent years as people become more aware of the negative impact cars have on the environment. Car-free cities are cities that have implemented measures to reduce the use of cars or eliminate them altogether, encouraging alternative modes of transportation such as walking, cycling, and public transport. In this essay, we will explore the benefits of car-free cities and the challenges they face in their implementation.  One of the primary benefits of car-free cities is the reduction in greenhouse gas emissions. Cars are one of the biggest contributors to air pollution, accounting for approximately 40% of greenhouse gas emissions in cities. By reducing the number of cars on the road, car-free cities can significantly decrease their carbon footprint, leading to a healthier and cleaner environment for their residents.  Another benefit of car-free cities is the improvement of public health. Air pollution from cars has been linked to numerous respiratory diseases, such as asthma, bronchitis, and lung cancer. By reducing the number of cars on the road, car-free cities can improve the air quality, leading to better health outcomes for their residents.  Car-free cities also promote a more active lifestyle, encouraging people to walk, cycle, or use public transport instead of driving. This can lead to improved physical fitness, reduced obesity, and lower rates of chronic illnesses such as diabetes and heart disease.  Despite the numerous benefits of car-free cities, they also face several challenges in their implementation. One of the biggest challenges is the cost of implementing such measures. Car-free cities require significant investment in infrastructure, such as bike lanes, pedestrian walkways, and public transport systems. This investment can be expensive, and some cities may not have the financial resources to implement such measures.  Another challenge faced by car-free cities is resistance from residents who are used to driving and may find it difficult to adapt to alternative modes of transportation. This resistance can be addressed through education and awareness campaigns that highlight the benefits of car-free cities and the health and environmental benefits of reduced car use.  In conclusion, car-free cities are an excellent solution to the negative impact cars have on the environment. By reducing the number of cars on the road, car-free cities can significantly decrease their carbon footprint, improve public health, and promote a more active lifestyle. While there are challenges in implementing such measures, the benefits of car-free cities make them a worthwhile investment for cities that are committed to improving the health and wellbeing of their residents.		1
Studying Venus Remains Worth the Risk  While exploring Venus presents clear hazards due to its extreme environment, the author of "The Challenge of Exploring Venus" makes a compelling case that studying this planet remains a worthy scientific pursuit. The information to be gained from Venus significantly outweighs the dangers involved, and with prudent planning and precautions, missions can be designed to maximize knowledge while minimizing risk.   Several key pieces of evidence in the article support continued Venus exploration. First, Venus represents an untouched scientific frontier with clues about the formation of terrestrial planets. Its surface pressures and temperatures recreate conditions unseen elsewhere in the solar system, offering a natural laboratory. Second, robotic probes have survived on Venus longer than expected, showing its atmosphere can be navigated. Advancements in heat-resistant materials also promise greater mission longevity. Finally, Venus may harbor clues about climate change and planet evolution, topics with pressing relevance on Earth.   The author acknowledges Venus is no place for sentient explorers. However, robotic missions can collect valuable geological, atmospheric, and chemical data while remaining remotely operated from Earth. With care taken in payload design, landing sites, and operation procedures, exploratory robots can significantly expand our understanding of Venus for acceptable risk levels. Overall, the plentiful scientific rewards and safeguarding strategies discussed make a strong case that Venus exploration merits continued support and resources, despite hazards, as part of humanity's drive to explore the unknown frontiers of our solar system.		1

With all the social media platforms and video call apps out there, it's way easier to stay in touch with loved ones who live far away. Did you know that only 10% of students in Generic_City participate in at least one extracurricular activity and only 4% of students at Generic_School as a sport, joining the yearbook committee, serving the student council, or any after school¬†club, the students at Generic_School would become more involved in their community and want to help their community for the better.¬†A study done by Harvard University in 2017 proved that only 30% of the students in Virginia participate in at least one extracurricular activity and of those students, 28% are active in their community and have helped their communities by fund raising¬†for an important cause, petitioning for changes in their communities, and encouraging good habits such as recycling and healthy eating habits. Although this percentage of students in Virginia is very low, the rate of students who are active in their community is very high, based on these numbers. This proves that if our students participate in extracurricular activities, they are also more likely to impact their communities for the better which is why we need this policy in our school. Not only could the students at Generic_School impact their communities for the better, but participating in extracurricular activities could also help our students make new friends and find new interests.  By requiring our young learners to participate in an extracurricular activity, we are also encouraging them to reach outside of their comfort zones and try something new. This new activity could help them make new friends and they may even find new and exciting interests that they never new they would like.¬†If our students stuck to the same routine every day and never tried anything new, they may never find any activities that may excite them and spark new interests in them. Therefore, our students would start to become bored in school and feel less encouraged to do well and study hard to get good grades.¬†When I was in the beginning of fifth grade, I felt excited to start off a new and fun year as a fifth grader. This excitement slowly started to wear off a quarter way through the year and I started to feel less encouraged to continue working hard and striving to get the best grades that I could. I was beginning to feel bored with the same routine that I had maintained over the past few years and I hoped that I could try something new and refreshing that would make me more excited about school and my everyday life. One day, my mom asked me if I wanted to try a dance class at a studio that I had never heard of. Out of pure excitement, I agreed and that whole week, I was looking forward to the day that I would go to dance class. When the day of the class came, I was shy, but I managed to make friends with all of the girls and I had found a new interest in dance. Not only did this new experience help me make new friends and find a new interest, but it also made me feel encouraged in school to keep working hard throughout the week until my weekly dance class on Saturday. My grades started to go up and I was more happy and encouraged to do well in everything I did. This new dance class had helped me find new friends, find a new interest, and get better grades. To this day, I still dance and I could not imagine my life without it.¬†Not only does requiring our students to participate in a new activity help them find new interests and make friends, but it also could help our students get into good schools in the future, and therefore get better jobs and become more successful.  By requiring our students to participate in at least one extracurricular activity, we could also be helping these students get into good colleges and we could be setting them up for a very bright future. With this new policy, our students will be able to add to their resumes that they have participated in a variety of activities that may seem very impressive to college school boards, as they tend to find interest in students who have a variety of extracurricular activities. After going to a great college, our students will be sent into interviews for jobs. With their resumes saying that they went to an impressive college, they will be accepted into their dream jobs. This amazing future for our students is all because of this policy. Without it, we would be denying our students from the future they deserve. A study by Yale University in 2018 has shown that 80% of colleges base their acceptances of students based on the variety of extracurricular activities that they are in. This proves that with our new policy, we could be helping our students get into better schools. Not only will this policy help our students have a bright future, but it will also help them become better students and adults in the future.  Generic_School needs to require our students to participate in at least one extracurricular activity because it would help our students become more active and involved in their communities, it would help them make new friends and help them find new interests, and it would help our students get into good colleges and get good jobs, leading them to the bright futures that they deserve. This policy would be helping our students in the long run, and I strongly encourage that you will decide to enforce this new rule.		0

Dear Principal,   I am writing to you regarding the reconsideration of the school's cell phone policy. Of the two options presented, I believe Policy 1 is better for our school.   Allowing students to bring phones but requiring them to be turned off during class time strikes the right balance. Phones have become an integral part of students' lives outside of school, so an outright ban may be unrealistic and cause frustrations. However, having phones out and potentially distracting during lessons is disruptive to learning.   Policy 1 respects that phones are a part of students' lives today, while still prioritizing an environment conducive to education during class time. Students would be able to stay connected with friends and family during breaks, which benefits their well-being and social lives. An outright ban may feel overly restrictive.  Importantly, Policy 1 sets a clear rule that phones do not interfere with instructional time. Teachers could focus fully on teaching without potential distractions. Students, too, could focus on learning without temptation to check phones under desks. This balanced approach considers the perspectives of both students and teachers.  In an emergency, allowing phones in cases but turned off could also provide reassurance for parents. Overall, Policy 1 adopts a common-sense stance that works with the reality of today's technology use, while still upholding schoolwork as the top priority during lessons. For these reasons, I believe it is the best option for our school. Please let me know if you need any clarification of my perspective.  Thank you for considering my input on this important decision.  Sincerely, [Your name]		1
Do you think summer projects should be teacher-designed or student-designed? In my opinion, summer project should be student-designed. For students, summer is a break from school; students should have the freedom to do a project based on what they want. Reasons why I believe summer projects should be student-designed is because it gives students the ability to be creative, they feel less pressured, and it gives them responsibility.  First reason why I believe summer projects should be student-designed is because it gives students the ability to be creative. If students come up with what their projects is based on, it shows their creativeness. They can describe and show their personality through their project. They can also show their character and more about who they are. This can be a opportunity for students to open up with their teacher and classmates. Students can come out their comfort zone and be unique when creating their project.  Second reason why I believe summer projects should be student-designed is because students feel less pressured. If students have a certain project, they feel more pressured to do exactly what the project is based on. The project may be based on a subject they may not feel comfortable with. If students have a student-designed project, they will avoid that conflict because they will be able to choose their own topic. This may also pressure students because they could get a project that doesn't appeal to their personality.  Third reason why I believe summer projects should be student-designed is because it gives students responsibility. Students will have all summer to create their project; if the project is not done, it shows they aren't responsible. The project shows if they can be able to do a project before the new school year begins. Certain students will prove they're able to complete a project throughout the summer. While others will prove they aren't responsible enough to complete a project. In addition, this will give them a task to do while they aren't in school.  In conclusion, I believe that summer projects should be student-based. My reasons on why I believe this should be a student-designed project is because it gives students the ability to be creative, they feel less pressured, and it gives them responsibility. A summer project should be a project you are comfortable with and can show how you unique every individual is. The project will also keep students feeling educated while not being in school.		0
As citizens, we all have a responsibility to do our part to protect the environment. One way we can do this is by limiting our car usage. Cars are a major source of pollution, and they contribute to climate change. By driving less, we can reduce our impact on the environment and help to create a cleaner, healthier planet.  There are a number of ways to limit our car usage. We can walk or bike to places instead of driving, carpool or take public transportation, or simply drive less often. If we all make an effort to make these changes, we can make a big difference.  According to the passage "How to Reduce Your Carbon Footprint", driving a car produces about 4.6 metric tons of carbon dioxide per year. This is more than any other form of transportation. By walking or biking instead of driving, we can reduce our carbon footprint significantly.  In addition to reducing our carbon footprint, limiting our car usage can also help us to save money. Gas prices are constantly rising, and by driving less, we can save money on our fuel costs. We can also save money on car maintenance and repairs.  Of course, there are some times when we need to drive. But if we can make an effort to limit our car usage, we can do a lot to protect the environment and save money.  So next time you're thinking about driving, consider walking, biking, or taking public transportation instead. It's good for the environment, it's good for your wallet, and it's good for your health.  In conclusion, limiting our car usage is a simple way to make a big difference. By making these changes, we can help to create a cleaner, healthier planet for ourselves and for future generations.		1

Dear Senator,  I am writing to you today to express my strong support for abolishing the Electoral College and electing the President of the United States by popular vote. I understand that this is a complex issue with strong arguments on both sides, but I believe that the benefits of a popular vote system far outweigh the costs.  First and foremost, a popular vote system would ensure that every vote counts. Under the current system, it is possible for a candidate to win the popular vote but lose the election. This happened in 2000, when Al Gore won the popular vote by over 500,000 votes but lost the election to George W. Bush by a narrow margin in the Electoral College. This is not only unfair to the voters of the losing candidate, but it also undermines the legitimacy of the presidency.  Second, a popular vote system would give all states a voice in the election. Under the current system, a few swing states receive most of the attention from presidential candidates. This is because these states are up for grabs and a small shift in the popular vote in these states can swing the election. As a result, candidates ignore states that are considered to be "safe" for one party or the other. This is not only unfair to the voters of these states, but it also means that the President is not necessarily elected by the majority of the American people.  Third, a popular vote system would make it easier for people to vote. Under the current system, voters must register to vote and then vote in person on Election Day. This can be a challenge for many people, especially those who have busy schedules or who live in rural areas. A popular vote system would allow people to vote by mail or early voting, which would make it easier for more people to participate in the election.  I understand that there are some who argue that the Electoral College is necessary to protect the interests of small states. However, I believe that this argument is outdated. In today's society, small states are no longer at a disadvantage. They have the same representation in Congress as large states, and they have access to the same resources. In fact, some small states have actually benefited from the Electoral College, as they have been able to elect Presidents who would not have won the popular vote.  In conclusion, I believe that the Electoral College is an outdated and unfair system that should be abolished. A popular vote system would ensure that every vote counts, give all states a voice in the election, and make it easier for people to vote. I urge you to support a constitutional amendment that would abolish the Electoral College and elect the President of the United States by popular vote.  Sincerely,  [Your name]		1

Dear Senator,  I am writing to you today to express my strong support for abolishing the Electoral College and electing the President of the United States by popular vote.  As you know, the Electoral College is a system in which each state is allocated a number of electors equal to its number of representatives in Congress, plus its two senators. The candidate who wins the popular vote in a state receives all of that state's electoral votes, with the exception of Maine and Nebraska, which award their electoral votes by congressional district.  This system is deeply flawed. It gives disproportionate power to small states, and it allows a candidate to win the presidency without winning the popular vote. This has happened five times in American history, most recently in 2016, when Donald Trump won the presidency with 306 electoral votes, but lost the popular vote to Hillary Clinton by nearly 3 million votes.  There are many reasons why the Electoral College should be abolished. First, it is undemocratic. In a democracy, the person who receives the most votes should win the election. The Electoral College system makes it possible for a candidate to win the presidency without winning the support of the majority of voters. This is simply not fair.  Second, the Electoral College system gives disproportionate power to small states. Each state, regardless of its population, has at least three electoral votes. This means that a vote in a small state is worth more than a vote in a large state. This is unfair to voters in large states, and it makes it harder for candidates to win the presidency without appealing to voters in small states.  Third, the Electoral College system is unpredictable. In some states, the popular vote is very close, but the winner takes all of the electoral votes. This means that a candidate can win the presidency by winning a small number of states by a narrow margin. This is not a fair system, and it makes it difficult for voters to know who will win the election.  I urge you to support abolishing the Electoral College and electing the President of the United States by popular vote. This is the only way to ensure that our elections are fair and democratic.  Thank you for your time.  Sincerely, [Your Name]		1

Schools should allow student-designed summer projects rather than teacher-designed projects. There are a few key reasons for this.   First, student-designed projects allow for more creativity and curiosity. When students get to choose their own topics of interest, they are more motivated to dive deeply into learning. Prescribed topics from teachers may not align with individual students' passions and curiosity. By giving students freedom of choice, they can explore subjects they genuinely want to learn more about.   Secondly, student-designed projects prepare students for the future better than teacher-designed ones. In college and later in careers, students and workers often must work independently to solve problems and complete tasks with less hand holding. Student-directed projects foster independence, time management, and problem-solving skills that are highly applicable for life after K-12 schooling. Being able to self-start and see long-term projects through completion is an important skill.   Finally, student-designed projects promote engagement and excitement for learning outside of the classroom. If students get to follow their own interests, they are more likely to enjoy spending time on their projects over summer break. Motivation and enthusiasm are key for learning to continue when formal classes are not in session. Teacher-designed assignments run the risk of feeling too much like homework or busywork if topics are not personally meaningful. When projects are self-directed, students are invested in learning simply for learning's sake.   In conclusion, summer projects are most effective for continuing students' education if projects are designed by the students themselves. A student-directed approach allows freedom for creativity, independence, engagement, and passion-driven learning - all elements that are critically important for high-quality learning outside of school. As long as guidelines are provided on objectives and quality standards, students should have autonomy to pursue topics they find intriguing over summer break.		1

 One topic that is frequently debated is whether or not schools should follow the model of extending the school day by two hours. Some people argue that because students can learn more, they would have more time to spend with friends. On the other hand, I believe that extending the school day by two hours would allow students to do homework, spend time with friends, and learn more.  One reason why schools could extend the school day by two hours is that many students struggle with their classes and need additional help from teachers. If schools extended the day, teachers could provide more time for students to ask questions and receive assistance in passing their classes. Students often have poor grades because they do not pay attention to their teachers while they explain, or because the class is boring or the teacher does not engage with students.  Another reason why schools could extend the school day by two hours is that students could participate in school activities or play sports like soccer, American football, basketball, and have more time to spend with friends. They could also help clean the school, decorate classrooms, or stay in the library and organize books or do homework. Additionally, students could use computers to search and find books they want to read.  A third reason why schools could extend the school day by two hours is that some students want to stay in the school to work on projects or homework because they do not have enough time to do so at home. Some students have jobs or other responsibilities outside of school, while others have a lot of homework from multiple classes, and this can make it difficult for them to keep up with their schoolwork. Teachers may become frustrated with students who do not complete their homework, and students may explain that they have too much homework from other classes and not enough time to do it all.  Finally, schools could extend the school day by two hours to give students more time to focus on their homework and improve their grades. Good grades and passing tests are essential for graduation, and if students have good grades, they will receive certificates of achievement from their school, and their families will be proud of them. They will graduate without any trouble, and universities will be more likely to accept them based on their grades and performance in college.  In conclusion, extending the school day by two hours would provide students with more time to learn, do homework, and spend time with friends. The use of facial recognition technology like the Facial Action Coding System to read students' emotional expressions in the classroom is problematic and an invasion of privacy. While identifying students' emotions could provide teachers insights to better engage students, this type of monitoring also raises serious ethical concerns.   On one hand, the technology aims to help teachers understand how their lessons are landing with students on an emotional level. Knowing when students appear bored, confused or frustrated could help teachers adapt their instruction in real-time to improve engagement and learning outcomes. Proponents might argue this leads to a more personalized education.  However, constantly monitoring students' facial expressions and private emotions without their consent crosses an important line. In the classroom, students should feel free to naturally experience a full range of reactions without fearing a computer system is over-analyzing every micro-expression. Emotions are complex and personal, and automatic classification by an algorithm may misconstrue true feelings or lack important context about individuals.  Additionally, using this type of surveillance could undermine the student-teacher relationship built on trust. Students may feel less comfortable openly expressing themselves if they know a computer is reporting details about their emotional state back to teachers and administrators. Over time, this lack of privacy could negatively impact psychological development and well-being.   In balancing the potential benefits with serious risks to student privacy and development, the downsides of conducting ongoing computerized emotional surveillance in the classroom seem to outweigh the advantages. While technology that provides insights to improve teaching has merit, reading students' private emotions without consent goes too far. Schools should pursue alternatives that respect student privacy and allow natural human relationships in the learning process to thrive. Overall, the concerns about students' well-being and rights outweigh using this technology without meaningful consent in the classroom setting.		1

And sometimes, people just aren't as invested in the project as everyone else, and that can be, like, really frustrating. Now and days, our world has transformed from using simple transportation to one source: the automobile. However, recent studies have shown our slow progression for the past years, discovering other ways of getting to point A to point B by having programs, reducing pollution and smog along the way, and living in an affordable economy.  To begin with, cities in our world have proven to be "carfree cities" by allowing programs to show other ways of transportation and reducing pollution and smog along the way. In Bogota, Colombia, a program where it is "a car free day", millions of colombians hike, bike, skate, or take buses to work and as Enrique rivera mentions in source 3, "It's a good opportunity to take away stress and lower air pollution paragraph 24". Colombia has been hosting this program since the 1990's and it has spread around the world the influence Colombia has done is beyond incredible. Although the program is not held everyday, it impacts the world slowly. Also, in source 2, the usage of car in France has decreased drastically because of the "intensifying smog paragraph 14".  Positive thinking is often associated with success and happiness, as it can lead to better relationships and outcomes. When people have a positive attitude towards others, they tend to receive the same positive attitude in return, creating a cycle of positivity that can make everyone feel happier.  This principle applies to various aspects of life, including school and work. By treating teachers and colleagues with respect and kindness, individuals can create a more positive and productive environment. This can lead to better grades, more opportunities, and a greater sense of fulfillment.  Moreover, having a positive attitude can also help individuals cope with difficult situations and challenges. When faced with adversity, a positive mindset can help individuals stay focused and motivated, leading to better outcomes and a greater sense of control over their lives.  However, it's important to note that negative thinking can also have a significant impact on individuals and those around them. A negative attitude can create a cycle of negativity, leading to misunderstandings, conflict, and a general sense of unhappiness.  Overall, having a positive attitude towards others is a powerful tool that can lead to greater happiness, success, and fulfillment. By focusing on the positive aspects of life and treating others with kindness and respect, individuals can create a more positive and productive environment for themselves and those around them.		1

Generic_Name  Mr. Generic_Name 10/11/20  Why People Should Always Get Multiple Opinions  When making an important decision, or just asking for advice, people should always talk to more than one person. Seeking multiple opinions will help them be more successful by giving you more views on a topic. If someone seek multiple opinions, they will make smarter, more knowledgeable¬†and better choices because they will help give you a more accurate response as well¬†as different opinions.  One key reason why someone should ask multiple people for their opinion is because they will get more accurate data. For example, If someone asked one person a question and they answered yes, then they would be more likely to agree with the person that answered, but if they asked ten people and only the first person said yes, then it would be unlikely for them to agree with the person that said yes. This means that people will be more informed when asking multiple people instead of one.  Another reason why someone should ask more than one person is because everyone has a different opinion. Their opinion could be based on their background, beliefs, ethnicity, wealth, gender and many other reasons. This means that it is important to ask multiple people because everyone thinks differently about certain topics. One example would be politics. People often have different political beliefs based on where they live, their race, their wealth, and other factors, because of this, it is important to ask people that are different from you in these categories. They could have a completely different opinion that you have never thought of, and could swing¬†your view on a issue.  Lastly, people that ask multiple other people for their opinions will often be more successful with whatever they are trying to do or achieve. If a someone asks multiple people, then the people asked will help them come to a decision. The decision that will be made will be informed by others that they ask, and will be better than the choice that they would have made if they had no help or advice.  Some people say that if someone asks multiple people for advice, that would mean that they would no longer be come up with an opinion for themselves. This is incorrect because a persons opinion is based on what other people say or do. With out other people to give advice, people would not be able to create the same opinions.  These are multiple reasons talking to more then¬†one person will help you get better advice than if you were to just get one opinion. Asking multiple opinions will give you a more accurate overall view on how people feel about something as well as help someone become more successful. Getting more than one opinion can even help people think about things they had not previously thought about or considered.   ¬† ¬†		0
 The electoral college is an electoral group that determines who will be elected as the president and vice president of the United States. The country is divided into 538 electors, and each state is allocated a certain number of electors based on its population. However, there is a debate about whether the electoral college works effectively and whether it should be abolished or reformed.   One of the main arguments in favor of the electoral college is that it gives each state a proportional representation in the selection of the president. This means that states with larger populations have more influence on the election than states with smaller populations. For example, California, Texas, and Florida have a combined total of 76 electors, which is more than half of the total number of electors in the country. This system ensures that the president is elected by the entire country, not just by large cities or states.  However, there are also arguments against the electoral college. One reason is that it can lead to a candidate ignoring certain states in favor of others. For example, in the 2000 presidential election, George W. Bush focused on Texas and Florida, while Al Gore focused on California and New York. This strategy worked for Bush, who won Texas and Florida, but lost California and New York by large margins. This means that a candidate may not be elected by the entire country, but rather by a small group of states.  Another argument against the electoral college is that it can lead to a candidate failing to campaign in certain states. In the 2016 presidential election, Donald Trump skipped campaigning in several states that were expected to vote for Hillary Clinton, such as California and New York. This strategy was successful, as Trump won several states in the Rust Belt that he had never campaigned in before.  There are also calls to abolish or reform the electoral college entirely. One proposed solution is to abolish the electoral college and have the president elected by a popular vote. This would ensure that the president is elected by the entire country, not just by a small group of states. Another proposed solution is to divide the electors by population, so that states with smaller populations have a greater say in the election.  In conclusion, the electoral college has both its advantages and disadvantages. It gives each state a proportional representation in the selection of the president, but it can also lead to a candidate ignoring certain states and failing to campaign in others. Whether the electoral college should be abolished or reformed is a matter of debate, but one thing is clear  C the selection of the president and vice president is of great importance to the entire country, and it should be done in a fair and democratic manner.		1

 The use of facial expression coding technology in classrooms is a topic that continues to spark debate among educators and parents. While some believe that such technology could be valuable in identifying students' emotional states and helping them perform better academically, others argue that it may invade students' privacy and have negative effects on their emotional development. In this essay, I will argue in favor of the use of facial action coding systems in classrooms, citing the example of the Mona Lisa and the findings from the article "Making Mona Lisa Smile."  Firstly, it is important to understand how facial action coding works. Essentially, the technology analyzes microexpressions on a person's face to determine their emotional state. The author of "Making Mona Lisa Smile" explains that the system was used to analyze the facial expressions of over 5,500 people in various settings, including in school classrooms, and found that it was able to accurately identify emotions with an accuracy rate of over 90%. The ability to accurately read and interpret facial expressions has the potential to revolutionize the way we teach and relate with our students.  In a classroom setting, the use of facial action coding technology could be useful in several ways. For example, it could help teachers identify students who are struggling or struggling to engage in class, enabling them to provide more targeted support. It could also be used to gauge students' motivation and interest in a particular topic, helping teachers tailor their lessons to better meet their students' needs. In addition, the use of this technology could help teachers identify any negative emotions or behaviors, such as bullying or isolation, allowing them to take action to create a more positive learning environment.  However, there are those who argue that the use of this technology could have negative effects on students' emotional development. They argue that the constant monitoring and analysis of facial expressions could make students feel uncomfortable and self-conscious about their emotions. Furthermore, it could be argued that the technology could be used to punish or shame students who are found to be expressing negative emotions, instead of providing them with the support they need to address the root causes of their struggles.  While these concerns are valid, they can be addressed through careful consideration of how the technology is used in the classroom. For example, it is important for teachers to communicate to students that the use of the technology is for their benefit and that their emotional well-being is a top priority. In addition, teachers should use the technology in a way that fosters positive emotions and behaviors, rather than punishing or shaming students. Ultimately, the use of facial action coding technology in classrooms is a valuable tool that has the potential to improve student outcomes, as long as it is used appropriately and ethically.  In conclusion, the Facial Action Coding System is a new and innovative technology that has the potential to revolutionize the way we teach and relate with our students. While concerns about the impact on students' emotional development are valid, they can be addressed through careful consideration and responsible implementation. By using this technology to accurately read and interpret facial expressions, teachers can gain valuable insights into their students' emotional states and use that information to create a more positive and effective learning environment. As the article "Making Mona Lisa Smile" demonstrates, this technology has already proven to be highly accurate and effective in identifying emotions, making it a valuable asset to any classroom.		1

 Technology has had a profound impact on society, changing the way we communicate, work, and live our lives. While technology has brought about many benefits, it has also created new challenges and problems.  One of the most significant ways that technology has changed our lives is through the way we communicate. With the rise of social media, instant messaging, and video conferencing, people can now connect with each other from anywhere in the world in real-time. This has made it easier for people to maintain relationships with friends and family, collaborate with colleagues, and access information from anywhere.  However, this increased connectivity has also led to a decline in face-to-face communication, as people often prefer to interact with others through screens rather than in person. This has led to concerns about the impact of technology on social skills, as well as the potential for misunderstandings and miscommunications to occur.  Another way that technology has changed our lives is through the way we work. With the rise of remote work, people can now work from anywhere, anytime. This has led to increased flexibility and productivity, as well as the ability to work from anywhere in the world.  However, this increased flexibility has also led to challenges, such as the need for self-discipline and motivation, as well as the potential for burnout and isolation. Additionally, remote work can make it difficult for people to collaborate and communicate effectively, as they may not have access to the same resources and tools as their colleagues.  Finally, technology has also had a significant impact on our health. While technology has brought about many advancements in medicine and healthcare, it has also led to new health problems, such as sedentary lifestyles and eye strain from prolonged screen use.  Additionally, technology has also been linked to increased rates of depression and anxiety, as people may feel disconnected from others and overwhelmed by the constant barrage of information and stimulation.  Overall, technology has had a profound impact on our lives, bringing about many benefits but also creating new challenges and problems. It is important for individuals and society as a whole to be mindful of these impacts and to use technology in a responsible and balanced way.		1
Imagine a life without cars. All those paved roads completely empty with no traffic and no honking horns. Sounds like a peaceful community to me. Limiting cars could be a huge advantage to our world. Reducing these big pieces of metal flying all over our roads could help our enviornment, save tons of money, and improve our saftey.  Recently, I've heard about all the well known car dealers pushing hybrid cars and trying to design a enviornment friendly vehicle. But in reality, the only big step to helping our planet is to reduce cars overall. Studies shown that green house gases are "... up to 50 percent in some car-intensive areas in the United States". Not only is the green house gas rate going up, but pollution, carbon emissons, and smog are as well. In Paris, France they had to ban driving for a couple of days as the pollution produced smog. "[Last] week Paris had 147 micrograms of particulate matter (PM) per cubic meter compared with 114 in Brussels and 79.7 in London...". The numbers keep rising in Europe and the USA. Picture what our enviorment is going to be like in 20 years if we keep this pace up. Without these machienes we could reduce the number of micrograms, produce the harmful gases from affecting the enviroment, and stop polluting the air we breathe.  Everyone likes to save money, whether it's with coupons or getting the best prices possible. So how would you feel if you had the abilty to save thousands of dollars a year? With reducing cars, you can save your money by public transportation, not paying for a car insurance, and not paying for a car in general. Not getting a car may seem strange as you need to get to location A and B. But in Vauban, Germany cars are not allowed and they seem to be doing just fine. Reports say "Vauban, home to 5,500 residents [within a rectangular square mile] may be the most advanced experiment in low-car suburban life". Even though they aren't aloud personal cars, they can walk, bike, or take a tram anywhere they need to go! Also in most parts of America they now have car-pooling apps, public transportation, and shared vans! So instead of paying huge amounts of money for gas, a car, and car insurance, why not just tag along for a ride or get some excersize! Also, the traffic jams that make people stressful and angry increase the crash rates as aggresive driving is very dangerous. To prevent that we can just walk, allowing us to enjoy our clean air and get excersize.  In conclusion, cars have changed our way of life for the good and the bad. Even though they help us get to our destination, they affect our enviornment, our money, and our saftey. If we reduce the amount of cars driven we can help our enviornment by lowering the rate of greenhouse gases, pollution, and carbon emissions. Also we save tons of money as we dont spend thousands of dollars on cars, and their needs. And finally, reducing cars saves tons of lifes as drunk driving and car crashes are avoided allowing the death and injury rates to decrease. So next time you're walking down the street, think about how your community would be without these machienes.    		0
For students considering graduating high school in less than the traditional four year time frame, there are several advantages and disadvantages of that choice to consider. The most significant advantage is cost savings; students can save up to half a year's tuition by graduating in three years compared to four. Graduating early also allows for increased college course work in the remaining time, giving students the opportunity to impress college admissions offices.   On the other hand, although graduating early will help save money, students who choose this route may not have had the opportunity to take as many classes as those who completed the traditional four years. When it comes to college preparedness, this is an important factor to consider. Additionally, graduating in three years may leave students feeling as though they are missing out on a major part of their high school experience in the form of sports teams, clubs, and other activities.  In my opinion, students should weigh the advantages and disadvantages of graduating early before making the decision to do so. Graduating early can be beneficial depending on the individual's goals and needs. It may be easier to get ahead in college preparedness through a three year plan, while maintaining the full high school experience and taking all the available classes may be the best fit for others. Ultimately, the decision is a personal one and should be taken into consideration with care.		1
 When it comes to exploring the vast expanse of space, Mars has always been a point of great interest for scientists and space enthusiasts alike due to its similarity with Earth and its potential to support life. However, one of the most intriguing phenomena on the red planet is the face that has been observed from orbit and is known as the "Face on Mars."  This natural formation has been visible for centuries, but it was not until the 20th century that scientists were able to get a more detailed understanding of its origins and composition. The Face on Mars is believed to be a large, ancient canyon system that has been eroded over time by the action of wind and water.  What makes the Face on Mars so fascinating is the way in which it seems to resemble a face, with its sinuous curves, deep crevices, and rounded features. Some scientists have even gone so far as to suggest that the formation may be the result of an extinct Martian civilization, with the shapes and patterns supposedly representing the features of some alien being.  Despite the many theories that have been put forward, no one knows for sure what caused the formation of the Face on Mars. Some scientists suggest that it may be the result of a massive volcanic eruption or the impact of a large meteorite, while others think that it may have been shaped by the action of rivers and lakes that flowed across the planet's surface millions of years ago.  What is clear, however, is that the Face on Mars is a remarkable testament to the forces of nature and the incredible variety of landscapes that can be found across the solar system. Whether it was formed by the work of an extinct Martian civilization or by the action of geological processes, the Face on Mars is an enigma that continues to intrigue and fascinate scientists and space enthusiasts alike.  In conclusion, the Face on Mars is an enduring mystery that has captured the imagination of people for centuries. While scientists have made some progress in understanding its origins and composition, the true nature of this remarkable formation remains unknown. Whatever it is, one thing is certain - the Face on Mars is a testament to the incredible diversity of landscapes and processes that can be found across the solar system, and a reminder of the limitless potential for exploration and discovery that lies within our reach.		1
 Facial Action Coding System (FACS)    Facial Action Coding System (FACS) is a method of scientific analysis of facial expression that was originally developed by Paul Ekman, Wallace V. Friesen, and Wallace S. Musa in the early 1970s. FACS is a highly detailed and systematic way of evaluating and categorizing facial movements during expression. The system is based on the idea that facial expressions are encoded as different patterns of muscle activation in the face, and that these patterns can be measured and analyzed scientifically.  FACS uses a combination of cameras, sensors, and computer software to record and analyze facial expression. The system is highly complex, with over 70 muscle groups in the face, each of which is capable of producing a wide range of movements. FACS researchers use this detail to break down facial expressions into smaller and more precise components, allowing for a more complete understanding of how the face is used to communicate emotions and other social cues.  One of the primary uses of FACS is in the field of emotion research. By analyzing the muscle movements of subjects while they are expressing various emotions, FACS researchers can identify specific patterns of activity that are associated with different emotional states. This information can then be used to develop more accurate models of emotion and to better understand the neural mechanisms underlying emotional processing.  FACS is also widely used in the field of forensic science for the identification of individuals based on their facial expressions. By recording and comparing the muscle patterns of different individuals during various facial expressions, FACS can help investigators identify suspects or determine the identity of victims based on their physical appearance.  In conclusion, Facial Action Coding System is a highly sophisticated method of scientific analysis that has revolutionized our understanding of facial expression. By breaking down facial expressions into smaller and more precise components, FACS has allowed researchers to identify specific patterns of activity that are associated with different emotional states and physical expressions. This information has a wide range of practical applications, from the study of emotion to forensic science, and will undoubtedly continue to generate new insights into this fascinating area of human behavior and communication.		1

Cell phones have become invaluable tools, especially for students. While cell phones offer many advantages, there are some potential drawbacks to using them in the classroom for educational purposes.  On the positive side, cell phones can be used to help students keep up with course work and class notes. Not only do they provide a convenient way to take notes, but they can also be used to access educational websites, virtual classrooms, and online videos and articles. Additionally, cell phones can be used for communication purposes, such as group collaboration on group projects or critical discussions of course material.  Despite the potential advantages, there are also some potential drawbacks to using cell phones in the classroom. For instance, students may be distracted by their phones, leading to a decrease in information retention and overall learning. Additionally, if cell phones aren‚Äôt used correctly, it could potentially lead to decreased grades. Proper responding to emails and texting in the classroom must be monitored to ensure cell phone use will be productive and not a distraction.  Overall, the use of cell phones in the classroom should not be discouraged, but instead should be used with caution and structure. When used correctly, cell phones offer an effective tool for students to access course information and engage in meaningful discussions. However, it is important to be mindful of how cell phone use can negatively affect student grades if not used properly.		1
Schools should allow student-designed summer projects instead of teacher-designed projects. There are a few key reasons for this.   First, student-designed projects will generate more interest and motivation from students. When students have autonomy in choosing their own summer learning activity, they are more likely to pick a topic that truly interests them. This makes it more enjoyable to work on over the summer break when students want to relax. Teacher-designed projects risk feeling like more required schoolwork, taking away from the freedom of summer.   Second, student-designed projects encourage independence, creativity and responsibility. By letting students choose their own projects, it teaches important life skills. Students have to think for themselves about what they want to learn more about. They have to come up with a creative idea and a plan to complete it. Being responsible for their own project over the summer builds self-reliance.   Finally, student-designed projects can be more tailored to individual interests. Teachers do not know each student's unique passions and hobbies as well as the students know themselves. By choosing topics they genuinely care about, students will get more out of the learning process. They can explore areas the regular curriculum does not reach. This makes learning more personalized and meaningful for each student.   In conclusion, schools should implement student-designed summer projects rather than teacher-assigned work. It fosters independence, motivation and learning tailored to each student's interests. By giving students autonomy over their break assignments, it enhances the learning experience and better prepares them for life beyond school. Summer is a time for students to pursue knowledge in their own way.		1

For example, imagine a student who didn't put in the effort to study for an exam and ended up failing. This experience could have been avoided if the student had approached the problem with a sense of urgency and a willingness to put in the necessary work. By putting in the effort to understand a problem, you may discover new ways to approach it or even find solutions you never thought possible. For instance, a person who has been struggling with a particular health issue may discover a new treatment option by approaching the problem with an open mind and a willingness to learn.  Lastly, if you don't approach a problem with a sense of purpose and a willingness to learn, you may end up repeating the same mistakes over and over again. For example, a person who has been struggling with a particular relationship issue may continue to repeat the same mistakes if they don't approach the problem with a sense of purpose and a willingness to learn. By approaching the problem with a positive attitude and a willingness to learn, you can break the cycle of repeating the same mistakes and start making progress towards a better outcome.  In conclusion, I believe that Duke Ellington's quote holds a great deal of wisdom and relevance in today's world. By approaching a problem with a sense of purpose and a willingness to learn, you can avoid regrets, discover new insights, and break the cycle of repeating the same mistakes. So, the next time you face a problem, remember that it's a chance for you to do your best and make progress towards a better outcome.		1

 As the world becomes increasingly aware of the importance of environmental sustainability, many cities are considering implementing car-free policies to improve air quality and reduce their carbon footprint. In this essay, we will examine the benefits and drawbacks of car-free cities and explore some potential solutions for cities that want to reduce their dependence on cars while still providing their citizens with convenient transportation options.  Car-free cities, as the name suggests, are cities where cars are not allowed to drive within their limits. This can include buses, trucks, and motorcycles, depending on the specific policies of the city. The main benefit of car-free cities is that they significantly reduce air pollution and greenhouse gas emissions. This is because cars are one of the largest sources of air pollution in urban areas, and preventing them from entering the city reduces the amount of emissions that are released into the atmosphere.  Car-free cities also offer a number of economic benefits. For one, they can help reduce traffic congestion, leading to shorter commute times and fewer sick days due to respiratory problems caused by exposure to polluted air. This can result in reduced healthcare costs, increased productivity, and overall economic growth for the city. Additionally, car-free cities can help increase tourism, as visitors who are looking for an eco-friendly vacation may be more likely to visit a city with a strong commitment to sustainability.  Despite these benefits, car-free cities also have potential drawbacks. One major concern is that the lack of cars may result in a decrease in economic activity, as businesses that rely on automobile access may be forced to relocate outside the city or lose customers. Additionally, the shift away from cars may require significant investments in alternative transportation options, such as public transit, bike lanes, and pedestrian walkways. These investments may not see immediate ROI, leading to frustration and concerns about the cost-effectiveness of the new policies.  In order to successfully implement car-free policies, cities will need to carefully consider their options and weigh the benefits and drawbacks. Some potential solutions include phasing in the restrictions gradually over time, allowing businesses that cannot adapt to the new policies to remain in the city, and investing in alternative transportation options that are tailored to the specific needs of the city. Additionally, city planners may need to consider the logistics of implementing car-free policies, such as the need for parking spaces and how to transport goods and services within the city.  In conclusion, car-free cities offer a number of benefits, but also have potential drawbacks. By carefully considering these factors, cities can implement sustainable transportation policies that balance economic growth with environmental protection. Ultimately, the goal should be		1
