Dear Principal Smith,  I am writing to you regarding the proposal to require all students to perform community service. On the one hand, there are good arguments for making community service mandatory. Volunteering benefits society by addressing important needs, and it can teach young people valuable lessons about citizenship and helping others. However, after consideration, I do not think community service should be obligatory for all students.   Requiring community service risks taking away students' freedom to choose how to spend their free time. For some, extracurricular obligations like sports, music, or jobs are just as important for their growth and development as volunteering. Mandatory service could create resentment if students feel like their valuable personal choices are being taken away. Not all personalities and career interests are well-suited to community service either. For community service to be meaningful, participants should feel motivated from within rather than being mandated to participate.  Instead of making service compulsory, I think a better approach is to encourage it through education about opportunities and the positive impacts of volunteering. Recognizing student volunteers with awards or mention in newsletters could further inspire others to get involved. For those who want real-world experiences to strengthen college applications, requirements for a certain number of volunteer hours could be an option. However, students should not be penalized if community service does not fit their priorities or talents.    In conclusion, while I support the values of community service, I do not think it should be universally required. Students will benefit most by having the freedom to explore service and extracurricular activities that match their diverse passions and goals. Encouraging volunteerism through positive promotion, rather than mandates, will instill lifelong habits of engagement and citizenship for those who wish to participate. Thank you for considering my perspective on this important issue.  Sincerely, [Your name]		1

 The Facial Action Coding System (FACS) is a new technology that uses cameras and computer algorithms to analyze facial expressions and identify the six basic emotions of joy, sadness, anger, fear, surprise, and disgust. While the FACS has been used for a variety of applications, including advertising and customer service, there are also potential uses for this technology in educational settings. In this essay, we will examine the potential benefits and drawbacks of using the FACS to read the emotional expressions of students in a classroom.  On the one hand, the use of this technology could be valuable in helping teachers to monitor student engagement and emotional wellbeing. For example, the FACS could be used to detect when a student is struggling with a particular concept and identify the emotion associated with that struggle, such as frustration or confusion. This information could then be used by the teacher to tailor their instruction to better meet the needs of the student and provide additional support when necessary.  Additionally, the FACS could be used to provide real-time feedback to students on their emotional expression. For example, if a student is expressing confusion, the teacher may be able to use the FACS to indicate that their facial expression is not clearly communicating their understanding. This feedback could help students to develop more effective communication skills and improve their overall emotional regulation.  However, there are also potential drawbacks to using the FACS in a classroom setting. One concern is that the technology may be used to invade students' privacy and make them feel uncomfortable. Students may feel that they are being watched and monitored without their knowledge or consent, which could lead to feelings of distrust and discomfort.  Furthermore, the accuracy of the FACS technology is not always reliably consistent. For example, the technology may be affected by factors such as lighting and camera placement, which could lead to false readings of emotions. This could result in misinterpretation of students' true emotional state and potentially lead to misguided interventions.  In conclusion, while the Facial Action Coding System has the potential to be a valuable tool in monitoring student emotional wellbeing, it is important to carefully consider the potential privacy concerns and limitations of the technology. As with any new technology, it is important to thoughtfully evaluate its potential applications and limitations before implementing it in a classroom setting. Ultimately, teachers should prioritize creating a safe and supportive learning environment that fosters student trust and wellbeing.		1

"Social media has become an integral part of our lives, but it's a debatable topic whether it has a significant impact on societal norms and values. In my opinion, social media has a profound effect on how we perceive things and behave in society. The constant use of platforms like Instagram, Facebook, Twitter, etc., influences our thoughts, beliefs, and actions.  Firstly, social media promotes unrealistic beauty standards that often lead to body shaming and low self-esteem. People are constantly bombarded with edited images of models and influencers, making them feel inadequate about their own bodies. This has led to an increase in eating disorders and other mental health issues, especially among teens and young adults.  Secondly, social media also plays a significant role in spreading hate speech and cyberbullying. With anonymity being easy to achieve online, people can say whatever they want without facing any consequences. This kind of behavior not only affects the victim but also normalizes such toxic behaviors in our society.  Lastly, social media can be a great tool for activism and raising awareness about important issues. It gives a voice to the marginalized communities and helps in creating a more inclusive society. For instance, movements like #MeToo and Black Lives Matter gained momentum because of social media.  Therefore, I believe that social media does have a significant impact on societal norms and values, both positively and negatively. It's up to us how we use these platforms and what kind of content we consume and promote."		1
The idea that problems, both good and bad, can contribute to personal growth and self-development is an insightful and often overlooked concept. On the surface, many of us tend to view problems as undesirable and something to be avoided. We try to take the paths least cluttered with obstacles  ?and who could blame us? After all, who wants to put themselves through the stress and anguish of tough times that come along with hard problems? Despite this understandable instinct, problems of any kind can be used to our advantage.   Good problems are those that stretch our abilities and allow us to develop new skills. By pushing our parameters and pushing through what we may feel to be our limits, we open ourselves to a world of possibilities. These problems can lend to personal growth and self-fulfillment, and open us up to possibilities we may not have previously considered.   Similarly, bad problems can also be used as a means of learning and growing. By actively engaging challenges and putting effort towards their solutions, we learn invaluable lessons about ourselves and the world around us. We may come to trust our own resilience, or perhaps understand our position in society a bit better. Even when the immediate outcome of solving a problem is not what we had originally hoped for, the process itself can produce insight into our strategies and approaches that can be useful in furthering our personal development.   Both good and bad problems are vital to our journey of self-discovery. By embracing what may initially appear to be unpleasant tasks, challenges, or experiences, we can use these difficulties to our advantage. We can choose to see adversity as an opportunity to grow and become the best version of ourselves.		1

The Facial Action Coding System should not be used in schools to help students. There are benefits to this system, but the bad outweigh the good. This technology used to reconize emotions will affect students in ways that aren't necessary, and cause unwanted problems in the classroom.  Firstly, the article metions this system being used on computers while students are working to analyze their emotions. The author writes " 'A classroom computer could recognize when a student is becoming comfused or bored,' Dr. Huang predicts. 'Then it could modify the lesson, like an effective human instructor'" (Alto 6). Having a computer watch students' facial expressions while working could make the students feel uncomfortable and give them anxiety. Being uncomfortable while working will effect the way a student learns. They will not be focusuing on the material they are learning, but instead the idea that they are being watched. This is a problem that's not needed in the classroom and can be avoided.  Secondly there are tons and tons of emotions a human can express. The author writes " Then Dr. Huang relies on the work of psychologists, such as Dr. Paul Eckman, creator of FACS. Eckman has classified six basic emotions- happiness, suprise, anger, disgust, fear, and sadness- and then associated each with characteristic movements of the facial muscles" (Alto 3). Having only classified six emotions, is not a very wide range. What if for example, a student were to show an emotion that the computer doesn't have programmed and reconizes it as somthing else, changing the lesson to fit the wrong emotion? This would cause the lesson to be changed when the student didn't need it to be. This creates a technology problem along with the problem of fixing the lesson and wasting time the student could be using to learn.  Lastly, having a computer analize a students emotions while working would leave the teacher with nothing to teach or help the students with. This might seem like a good thing at first, but teachers create the classroom atmosphere and keep students ingaged in learning. Why have a computer analyze student emotions when teachers have been doing it perfectly for years?  The Facial Action Coding System is a great advance in technology, but when it comes to schools, the System should not be used. It only creates problems that are not needed. These problems could be avoided by not using the system.		0
Many Americans today use cars to commute from one place to another, like work or going to school. However, in recent times, car usage has significantly decreased due to its beneficial effect on many communities. Based on the information given, there are many advantages of limiting car usage.  One of many advantages of limiting the usage of cars is that it can help the community. With lower car usage, the community's environment can potientally become much better. According to Source 2, France's partial driving ban caused its congestion to go "down 60 percent... after five-days of intensifying smog." This drastic change in France's car traffic prevented further pollution and smog, which hurts the community. Addtionally, limiting car usage can push more people into excercising more. In Bogota, Colombia, many Colombians "hiked, biked, skated..." during their car-free days (source 3). Also, many "parks and sports centers have bloomed throughout the city" (source 3). With an increase of excercise, the community's people will not only become healthier and fitter, but prevent any more damage to the community.  Futhermore, lowering car uage will benefit the community's patrons by providing a cleaner lifestyle. With limiting their car usage, the people of the community will save more money.  While summer is meant to be a break from the regular school workload, having some academic activities over the summer can help students maintain their skills and knowledge. When it comes to summer projects, I believe they are best when designed by students themselves rather than being completely teacher-assigned.   Allowing students to design their own summer projects fosters independence and encourages creativity. When students have autonomy over their work, they are more invested in the learning process. They can choose topics that genuinely interest them rather than just fulfilling a teacher's requirements. This makes the work feel less like a chore and more like an opportunity for exploration. Students may pick subjects connected to their hobbies or extracurricular interests, maintaining enthusiasm for other areas of learning outside the classroom.  Furthermore, student-designed projects allow for flexibility. Every student has different strengths, weaknesses, and schedules over the summer. Some may have other commitments like summer camps, jobs, or family vacations that limit their time. By permitting students to tailor projects to their individual schedules and needs, no one feels overwhelmed or left behind. Students understand their own pacing better than teachers can from the outside.   Of course, completely unguided work risks students selecting inappropriate or low-effort topics. Therefore, there should still be guidelines and teacher approval for project ideas. Regular checkpoints also keep students accountable without being too restrictive. The role of teachers then becomes advising students and facilitating their self-directed learning, rather than strictly assigning tasks.   In conclusion, summer projects are most beneficial when designed by the students themselves within clear parameters set by teachers. This balances freedom with oversight, keeps students engaged, and treats them as autonomous learners ready to take responsibility for their education. Overall student performance and retention of knowledge is best supported through student-driven academic work over the summer break.		1
 Car-free cities are becoming more popular every year. These are cities where cars are limited or completely banned, and people are encouraged to use alternative modes of transportation such as walking, biking, public transportation, or electric scooters. Car-free cities have several benefits, including improved air quality, safer streets, reduced traffic congestion, and increased social and economic opportunities.  One of the main benefits of car-free cities is improved air quality. Cars are a major source of air pollution, releasing harmful emissions such as carbon dioxide, nitrogen oxides, and particulate matter. By limiting or banning cars, car-free cities can reduce air pollution and improve the health of their citizens. This in turn can lead to a decrease in healthcare costs and an increase in lifespan.  Another benefit of car-free cities is safer streets. When cars are limited or banned, there are fewer accidents on the roads. This can lead to a lower number of injuries and fatalities, as well as a reduction in property damage. Furthermore, car-free cities tend to be more pedestrian-friendly, with wider sidewalks, better lighting, and more crosswalks, which can help to reduce the number of accidents caused by pedestrians and drivers alike.  Reduced traffic congestion is another key benefit of car-free cities. Traffic congestion is a major problem in many cities, leading to long commute times, higher fuel costs, and decreased productivity. By encouraging people to use alternative modes of transportation, car-free cities can reduce the number of cars on the roads, leading to less congestion and more efficient transportation systems.  Finally, car-free cities can provide increased social and economic opportunities. By limiting or banning cars, car-free cities can create more space for public parks, community centers, and other public spaces. This can lead to an increased sense of community, as people gather together in these spaces to socialize and participate in community activities. Additionally, car-free cities can also create new economic opportunities, with more businesses catering to people who are not driving, such as bike repair shops, car-sharing services, and electric scooter rental companies.  In conclusion, car-free cities offer numerous benefits, including improved air quality, safer streets, reduced traffic congestion, and increased social and economic opportunities. While car-free cities are not a solution for everyone, they do provide a viable alternative for those looking to reduce their carbon footprint, improve their health, and engage with their communities in a more meaningful way. As such, car-free cities are worth considering for any city looking to build a more sustainable future.		1

 Working with a group has its own set of advantages and disadvantages. On the one hand, it allows individuals to collaborate, learn from each other, and be more social. On the other hand, it can lead to pressure, distractions, and a loss of individuality. When working alone, individuals have the freedom to work at their own pace, but may miss out on the benefits of collaboration and social interaction. Ultimately, the choice between working alone or in a group depends on the individual's goals, preferences, and circumstances.  One of the main advantages of working in a group is the ability to collaborate and learn from one another. When individuals work together, they can share ideas, resources, and expertise, leading to a more efficient and effective outcome. Additionally, working in a group can provide opportunities for social interaction, which can be beneficial for personal growth and development.  However, working in a group can also be challenging. For example, individuals may be pressured to meet certain deadlines or expectations, which can lead to stress and conflict. Additionally, distractions and interpersonal dynamics can arise, which can be difficult to manage.  When working alone, individuals have the freedom to work at their own pace and in their own way. This can be beneficial for individuals who prefer a more structured and focused approach to work. However, working alone can also lead to feelings of isolation and a lack of social interaction, which can be detrimental to personal well-being.  Ultimately, the choice between working alone or in a group depends on the individual's goals, preferences, and circumstances. Some individuals may thrive in a group setting, while others may prefer to work alone. It is important for individuals to consider the potential benefits and drawbacks of each option and choose the one that best suits their needs.		1
Dear Senator,  I am writing to you today to express my strong support for abolishing the Electoral College and electing the president by popular vote. I believe that this change is necessary to ensure that our elections are fair and representative of the will of the people.  The Electoral College is an outdated system that was designed to give more power to small states. However, this system is no longer necessary or fair. In recent years, there have been several elections in which the candidate who won the popular vote lost the election. This is undemocratic and unrepresentative of the will of the people.  In 2000, George W. Bush won the presidency even though he lost the popular vote to Al Gore by 543,816 votes. This was a close election, but it was clear that the majority of voters wanted Gore to be president. The Electoral College system prevented this from happening.  In 2016, Hillary Clinton won the popular vote by 2.8 million votes, but Donald Trump won the election. This was a much larger margin of victory, but it was still clear that the majority of voters wanted Clinton to be president. The Electoral College system once again prevented this from happening.  These two elections are just two examples of how the Electoral College has failed to represent the will of the people. I believe that it is time to abolish this outdated system and elect the president by popular vote. This would ensure that every vote counts and that the president who is elected is the person who the majority of voters want.  I know that some people argue that the Electoral College is necessary to protect the interests of small states. However, I believe that this is not a valid argument. The Electoral College gives more power to small states than they would otherwise have, but this does not mean that they are not represented in the government. Senators and representatives are elected by popular vote, so small states have a voice in Congress.  I urge you to support a bill that would abolish the Electoral College and elect the president by popular vote. This change is necessary to ensure that our elections are fair and representative of the will of the people.  Thank you for your time.  Sincerely, Your Name		1
The advantages of limiting car usage are numerous and well-documented. Limiting car usage can help to improve air quality, reduce traffic congestion, and promote physical activity. In addition, limiting car usage can save money and improve quality of life.  One of the most important advantages of limiting car usage is that it can help to improve air quality. Cars are a major source of air pollution, and reducing the number of cars on the road can lead to cleaner air for everyone. In fact, a study by the Environmental Protection Agency found that reducing vehicle emissions by just 1% can save up to 4,000 lives each year.  Limiting car usage can also help to reduce traffic congestion. Traffic congestion is a major problem in many cities, and it can lead to a number of problems, including increased pollution, lost time, and stress. Reducing the number of cars on the road can help to alleviate traffic congestion and make it easier for people to get around.  In addition to improving air quality and reducing traffic congestion, limiting car usage can also promote physical activity. When people walk or bike instead of driving, they get more exercise, which can help to reduce their risk of obesity, heart disease, and other health problems. In fact, a study by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention found that people who walk or bike for transportation are more likely to meet the physical activity guidelines than people who drive.  Finally, limiting car usage can also save money. Car ownership and operating costs can be a major expense, and reducing the number of cars in a household can save a significant amount of money. In addition, people who walk or bike instead of driving can save money on gas, parking, and insurance.  In conclusion, there are many advantages to limiting car usage. Limiting car usage can help to improve air quality, reduce traffic congestion, promote physical activity, and save money. If you are looking for ways to improve your health, save money, and reduce your impact on the environment, consider limiting your car usage.		1

### Limiting Car Usage: The Advantages  In recent years, there has been a growing movement to limit car usage. This movement has been driven by a number of factors, including concerns about air pollution, traffic congestion, and the need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.  There are a number of advantages to limiting car usage. First, it can help to improve air quality. Cars are one of the major sources of air pollution, and reducing car usage can help to reduce emissions of harmful pollutants like nitrogen oxides and particulate matter. Air pollution is a major health concern, and reducing it can have a significant impact on public health.  Second, limiting car usage can help to reduce traffic congestion. Traffic congestion is a major problem in many cities, and it can waste time, fuel, and money. Reducing car usage can help to ease traffic congestion and make travel more efficient.  Third, limiting car usage can help to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Cars are a major source of greenhouse gas emissions, and reducing car usage can help to reduce our impact on climate change. Greenhouse gas emissions are a major cause of climate change, and reducing them is essential to protecting our planet.  Fourth, limiting car usage can help to promote physical activity. When people walk or bike instead of driving, they get more exercise. Physical activity is important for good health, and promoting it can help to reduce obesity and other chronic diseases.  Fifth, limiting car usage can help to build community. When people walk or bike instead of driving, they are more likely to interact with their neighbors. This can help to build a sense of community and make neighborhoods more livable.  In conclusion, there are a number of advantages to limiting car usage. Limiting car usage can improve air quality, reduce traffic congestion, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, promote physical activity, and build community. If we want to create a healthier, more sustainable future, we need to find ways to limit our reliance on cars.  In addition to the advantages listed above, limiting car usage can also save money. Cars are expensive to purchase, maintain, and insure. When people walk, bike, or take public transportation, they save money on these costs. In some cases, they may even be able to get rid of their car altogether, which can save them even more money.  Limiting car usage can also have a positive impact on the environment. When people drive less, they produce fewer emissions of greenhouse gases and other pollutants. This helps to improve air quality and reduce climate change.  Overall, there are many good reasons to limit car usage. It can save money, improve health, and protect the environment. If we all make an effort to drive less, we can make a big difference for the planet.		1
The "four-day school week" idea has the potential to be both helpful and detrimental for students. In certain scenarios, the increased time for rest and relaxation could result in a decrease in student stress, allowing them to give their best efforts in class. However, the shorter school week could reduce the students' amount of time to complete other activities like sport or extracurriculars. Additionally, there is a chance that it may have a lingering negative impact on students' future success as fewer days in the school week could equate to less knowledge and a lack of preparation for college or the workforce.		1

His solution is to fly above the surface where its still pretty hot, but nothing compared to the surface. He also states how the atmospheric pressure is 90 times greater than Earth's.  As a result of the ongoing search for extraterrestrial life, scientists have discovered a variety of unusual events and phenomena on the surface of Mars. One of the most intriguing discoveries made on Mars in recent years is the face-like structure located in the Valles Marineris canyon. This face-like pattern has captured the attention of many scientists and laypeople alike, leading to much discussion and speculation about its origins and potential significance. The face on Mars is a fascinating subject that has sparked many theories about the existence of intelligent life on the red planet, as well as the possibility of extraterrestrial forces at work.  The first image of the face on Mars was taken by NASA's rover, Opportunity, in 2005. The rover was exploring the Valles Marineris canyon, which is one of the largest canyons on Mars. As the rover moved through the canyon, it captured images of the Martian surface, including the face-like structure. Since then, other spacecraft, such as the Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter, have continued to document the face and take high-resolution images, allowing researchers to gather more information about its shape and features.  Despite the impressive features of the face on Mars, many scientists are skeptical of its origins. Some believe that the face is actually a form of natural sedimentation, caused by the movement of water and wind on the Martian surface. Others believe that the face is the result of volcanic activity, with eruptions and lava flows forming the patterns. Still, others speculate that the face may be a result of some form of extraterrestrial activity, with aliens either creating the patterns or leaving behind some form of technology on the surface of Mars.  One theory suggests that the face on Mars may be a form of artificial construction, created by an intelligent civilization that once inhabited the red planet. This theory is based on the idea that intelligent beings may have had the ability to terraform the Martian surface and create structures that could withstand the harsh Martian environment. Supporters of this theory point to the impressive scale and intricacy of the face, arguing that it is unlikely to have been created by natural processes alone.  However, skeptics of this theory argue that there is little evidence to support the idea that intelligent life ever existed on Mars. While some have suggested that the face may be a form of communication or warning from an extinct civilization, others argue that it is too simplistic to believe that aliens could have left behind such a structure with no discernible purpose.  Overall, the face on Mars remains a fascinating and mysterious subject that has captured the imagination of many people. While there is still much to be learned about the origins and significance of the face, it continues to inspire curiosity and wonder about the possibility of extraterrestrial life on the red planet. Whether it is a natural formation, the result of volcanic activity, or an artifact of an extinct civilization, the face on Mars is a testament to the ongoing search for answers to the age-old question: Are we alone in the universe? As we continue to explore the depths of the cosmos, the discovery of the face on Mars serves as a reminder that we have much to learn about the strange and wondrous phenomena that exist beyond our own planet.		1

As a high school student, I have witnessed firsthand the increasing use of social media platforms by my peers and the general public. While social media has its benefits, such as enabling us to stay connected with friends and family, it also poses a significant risk to our privacy. The amount of personal information shared online has increased dramatically, and this trend is likely to continue. Therefore, I strongly believe that there is a need for stronger privacy protections on social media.  One of the main reasons why we need stronger privacy protections on social media is to prevent identity theft. Cybercriminals can easily access our personal information, such as our full names, birth dates, addresses, and phone numbers, which we often share on social media platforms without giving it much thought. This information can then be used to steal our identities, open credit card accounts in our names, or commit other fraudulent activities. Stronger privacy protections would make it more difficult for cybercriminals to access our personal information, reducing the risk of identity theft.  Another reason why we need stronger privacy protections on social media is to protect our reputations. Many people share personal information, photos, and videos on social media without considering the potential consequences. This information can be easily accessed by employers, college admissions officers, and others who may use it to make decisions about us. If inappropriate or embarrassing content is shared online, it can damage our reputations and have long-term consequences. Stronger privacy protections would give us more control over who can access our personal information, reducing the risk of reputational harm.  Finally, stronger privacy protections on social media are needed to protect our mental health. Social media can be a breeding ground for cyberbullying, which can have serious consequences for our mental well-being. Cyberbullying can lead to anxiety, depression, and even suicide. Stronger privacy protections would make it more difficult for cyberbullies to target us, reducing the risk of mental health issues associated with social media use.  In conclusion, the rise of social media has led to an increase in the amount of personal information shared online, which poses significant risks to our privacy. Identity theft, reputational harm, and mental health issues are just a few of the potential consequences of sharing too much information on social media. Therefore, I strongly believe that there is a need for stronger privacy protections on social media to mitigate these risks. As users, we have a right to control who can access our personal information, and		1
Oil has been linked to numerous health effects and can adversely affect students ?performance in school. Studies have found that diets high in processed foods that typically contain trans-fats, saturated fats, and other unhealthy components due to the processing of regular oils can cause states of fatigue, difficulty concentrating in school and decreased academic performance. This is why some people believe that school cafeterias should not change their food.   On the other hand, replacing unhealthy processed oils with healthy, unsaturated vegetable oils, such as olive or sunflower oil, can contribute to better nutrition, leading to increased energy, mental clarity, and better academic performance. Consequently, many people argue that school cafeterias should update their offerings to include healthier alternatives in order to promote better nutrition and academic performance in school.		1

 Problems are opportunities for growth and improvement. I wholeheartedly agree with this statement because of several reasons. Firstly, if you don't take action to address a problem, it will only worsen and become more difficult to solve. Secondly, facing challenges can make you feel more competitive and motivated to overcome them. Lastly, having the support of friends and family can make all the difference in solving a problem.  When faced with a problem, it's important to take responsibility for it and do your best to find a solution. For example, if someone is constantly bullying you, it's important to take action and address the issue. Ignoring the problem will only make it worse and more difficult to solve in the future.  It's important to remember that you are not alone when facing problems. Having the support of friends and family can provide a fresh perspective and help you find solutions that you may not have considered on your own. Additionally, talking to someone about your problems can help alleviate stress and make you feel better.  In conclusion, problems are opportunities for growth and improvement. By taking action, staying motivated, and having the support of friends and family, you can overcome any challenge that comes your way.		1

Although some may disagree that student projects should be designed by teachers, it should be known that this is not true.  Students creating their own summer projects can benefit them as students. Assignments that are completed by students are created by teachers, followed by a due date in which it is to be completed. After the assignment is completed the moving on to the next. Over time assignments become a chore and are less likely to be completed by students. Allowing students the chance to create their own summer project that they would truly excited to work. Through their own creation topics that students are interested about can be integrated into the summer project. Even though the summer project could be less structured it would completed time and time again. Having created their own assignments students would better understand what is to be expected in the terms of how to not only completed but also pass. Once on summer break students are unable to contact teachers if they have any questions about the project through having created it themselves this would eliminate the unanswered questions. If students were allowed to create their own summer projects it would give them a sense of control over their learning that is often lost throughout the school year. Some students can become detached from their learning with endless amounts of work that is assigned to them. Through the creation their summer projects it would also allow students to place their input and become more hands on within their learning.  Through creating their own assignments, students are able to build qualities that are helpful in a work environment. The process of coming up with rubrics and topics in which the assignment could be upon can be difficult. Team collaboration is vital for creating an assignment along side teachers and other students. Having the ability to voice an idea or criticism¬†can be useful not only within school but also in an work environment. Not only having to create but also complete their assignment helps develop a sense of work ethic that is¬†helpful in any situation. Students often rush to complete assignments very last minute and having formulated the assignment they would have a better understanding of how to space out their time to complete the summer project correctly. Along with school¬†assignments this skill can be applied to any work place.  Summer projects can help extend learning outside of school during summer break. Through students creating their own summer project there is a better understanding of the project but also an excitement to complete it. Having created their project a sense of control over students learning can be gained which is often lost throughout the school year. Those who oppose may state that teachers should create summer projects because they have more experience than students and that teachers are able to introduce new topics to students. Distance learning is becoming an increasingly popular option for students who are looking to attend classes from the comfort of home. There are a few key pros and cons that should be considered when deciding if distance learning is the right option for individual students.   One of the main advantages of distance learning is the convenience that it offers. Students have greater flexibility in terms of when and where they can attend class, making it easier for them to maintain concentration. However, there is still an element of distraction from the home environment, particularly when it comes to online shopping.   Another benefit of distance learning is that students have access to a wide range of learning materials, such as online books and videos, making it easier to acquire the resources necessary for their studies. Along with this, distance learning offers lower costs than traditional schooling, making it an attractive option for families with financial constraints.   Yet, one of the main disadvantages of distance learning is the lack of social contact with peers and teachers. Additionally, online bullying is a real issue, and it can be harder to detect and prevent than in-person bullying. For these reasons, some students may benefit from the increased support and social interaction of traditional schools.   In conclusion, distance learning is a great option for students who are looking to attend classes from home. That being said, it‚Äôs important to consider the various pros and cons before committing to a distance-learning course.		1
  Dear [State Senator],  I hope this letter finds you well. As you consider the matter of the Electoral College and the process of electing the President of the United States, I wanted to share my thoughts on why I believe it is important to retain this system.  One of the primary arguments in favor of the Electoral College is that it ensures a more reliable and decisive outcome in the presidential election. As Judge Richard A. Posner notes in "In Defense of the Electoral College," the Electoral College system has produced only five instances of a tie in the electoral vote, and none of these have resulted in a catastrophic crisis for the country (Posner 3). In contrast, a popular vote system would leave the outcome of the election vulnerable to manipulation and fraud, as we saw in the 2000 presidential election. The Electoral College also provides a sense of certainty and finality to the election process, as the candidate who receives the most electoral votes is guaranteed to be the next President.  Another advantage of the Electoral College is that it encourages presidential candidates to campaign and pay attention to a wide range of states, rather than solely focusing on heavily Democratic or Republican areas. As Bradford Plumer notes in "The Indefensible Electoral College," this forces candidates to consider the concerns and needs of voters in various regions of the country, instead of simply relying on their base of support (Plumer). This helps to promote a more inclusive and representative government, as candidates must take into account the views and concerns of a diverse range of voters.  Furthermore, the Electoral College has a long and storied history in the United States, with roots dating back to the founding of the country. As Posner notes, the Electoral College has been		1
Extra curricular activities give students an opportunity to be on a team or with a group of people with shared interests as them. They are very beneficial for students, but many kids don't participate¬†in after school activities because they are to busy with school.  Because some parents force there kids to spend little to no time with there friends and hours studying. Their kids may end up with little social skills and poor mental health. Though excessive time studying may seem beneficial; to much time studying actually harms the students. Mandatory extra curricular activities would help to give students more control over their lives and let them to have a social life. Many adults would have never thought to try any after school activities if their school didn't force them to, yet so many parents don't allow there kids to participate in those activities that they once loved as a kid. A lot of students feel at ease when doing a sport or playing their instrument, and they never would have thought to try it if they had no reason to. Making students participate in extra curricular activities is beneficial for their physical and mental health because it helps students make more friends and find their passion.  Since there is so much pressure for student to maintain a high GPA, some students make studying more of a priority than their social life. It gets so extreme to the point where some students spend all there time doing homework, but spend little to no time hanging out with their friends. This makes students struggle socially. Extra curricular activities give students a chance to take a break from homework and be in a group of people with the same interests and same goal as them. Pushing students to do extra curricular activities would help them to spend less time studying and more time spent on an activity that they love. There are a lot of students that are strong academically, but many of those students can't communicate with other people or work in a team, so no matter how smart they are they wouldn't excel in any job. Because every job requires communication and social skills, students need to develop those skills while still in school to get a secure job in their future. Increasing communication and teamwork is not the only reason that after school activities are beneficial.  There are many adults that would have never found their passion if there weren't activities for them to try. Since stress is only increasing for students, they tend to spend more time studying trying to improve already good grades then doing an activity that they love. Students feel so stuck feeling like they can only do school work, but when they have other activities it can really clear their head; as well as make them realize that they work well in a certain field. For example if a student were to join the SCA and like it they could realize that they want to take on more leadership roles and one day run a company. If that student was forced to study and had no free time to be on the SCA they may have never realized how much they like leadership roles. They may have never gotten the chance to start the company and there life would be so different. Plus students are more likely to get accepted in a good college for continuing with an activity that they love with a slightly lower GPA then having a perfect GPA, never have participating in any extra curricular activities, so after school activities are also helping students to get into college.  A lot of extra curricular activities are offered, and by making them mandatory it will make many students realize that they are passionate about some things. Whether that activity be a sport, an instrument, or a leadership role. While there is something out there for everyone students wanting to participate in an activity isn't as common as many may think. Pushing students to find their activity will help them in their future. There is no way out of communication and teamwork so giving students the opportunity to learn those skills in school only benefits them. By not enforcing extra curricular activities on students, many students futures are being harmed. By not letting kids have social lives or giving students the opportunity to find their passion students are going to struggle in their future adult life a lot more then they ever needed to struggle. This can be avoided by just simply making after school activities mandatory; having students focus on things other then school and studying.		0
 The electoral college is a group of electors appointed by the political parties who ultimately decide the outcome of a presidential election in the United States. The system has been in place since the founding of the country, and it is a contentious topic that has been debated for decades. Some argue that the electoral college works well, while others argue that it is outdated and should be abolished. In this essay, I will explore both sides of the debate and determine whether the electoral college system is effective or not.  On one hand, supporters of the electoral college system argue that it works well because it gives weight to the votes of each state based on its population. The system reflects the will of the people, and it ensures that no one state has too much influence over the election. In this way, the electoral college ensures that political power is distributed more evenly throughout the country.  Furthermore, proponents of the electoral college argue that the system helps to prevent the election from being dominated by large urban areas. Instead, it gives voters in rural and urban areas an equal voice in the election. As a result, the country as a whole gets a better representation in the White House.  On the other hand, opponents of the electoral college system argue that it is outdated and doesn't reflect the will of the people. They claim that the system is now skewed towards the states with the highest population, and that smaller states are being unfairly ignored. This can lead to candidates concentrating their efforts in states with larger population concentrations, leaving other states without the same level of representation.  Furthermore, opponents of the electoral college argue that the system does not accurately reflect the will of the people because it can result in a candidate winning the popular vote nationwide but losing the election. For example, in the 2000 presidential election, Al Gore won the popular vote by over 500,000 votes, but he lost the election because he didn't win the electoral vote in Florida.  In conclusion, the electoral college system is a contentious topic that has been debated for decades. While supporters argue that the system works well and reflects the will of the people, opponents argue that it is outdated and doesn't accurately reflect the will of the people. Ultimately, the effectiveness of the system will depend on the political climate and the values of the people.		1
  Dear [State Senator],  I am writing to express my opinion on the Electoral College system used to elect the President of the United States. As a concerned citizen and student of politics, I believe that the Electoral College is a fair and effective method of choosing the President, and I urge you to support its continuation.  One of the main arguments against the Electoral College is that it is undemocratic and unfair to voters. However, as Bradford Plumer argues in his article "The Indefensible Electoral College," the winner-take-all system used in most states means that candidates only focus on swing states, ignoring the needs and concerns of voters in other states. In contrast, the Electoral College requires candidates to have a broader appeal, as they must win votes from across the country to be elected. This leads to a more diverse and representative candidate pool, as candidates must appeal to a wider range of voters (Plumer).  Another argument against the Electoral College is that it can lead to a tie in the electoral vote, resulting in a congressional decision. However, as Judge Richard A. Posner argues in his article "In Defense of the Electoral College," this is unlikely to happen, as the total number of votes is an even number. Moreover, the Electoral College ensures that a candidate must receive a majority of votes, rather than a plurality, to be elected. This prevents the situation where a candidate wins the popular vote but loses the election due to a lack of support in key states (Posner).  Furthermore, the Electoral College encourages candidates to campaign extensively in all states, rather than focusing solely on swing states. This means that voters in all states are more likely to receive attention and information from the candidates, leading to a		1

Dear Principal,   I am writing to provide my perspective on the school's cell phone policy options under consideration. Of the two possibilities, I believe Policy 1 is the better choice as it allows a reasonable use of technology while still supporting an effective learning environment.  Policy 1 respects that cell phones are now an integral part of students' lives outside of school. For many students, keeping in touch with family and friends during free periods is important. By permitting phones during lunch and breaks as long as they are off in class, this policy accommodates modern communication needs while also enforcing focus on schoolwork when lessons are taking place. A strict ban under Policy 2 is unrealistic given how intertwined phones are with daily life now.   Additionally, allowing controlled phone use per Policy 1 can help students feel more trusted and responsible. If given guidelines rather than prohibitions, students are more likely to properly follow the rules. By contrast, an outright ban may cause unintentional rebellion or disobedience. Treating high schoolers with appropriate freedom balanced with structure fosters maturity and citizenship.     Of course, limiting cell phone distraction during academic time remains key. Policy 1 directly addresses this concern by requiring phones be off in class. This balanced approach supports learning while still acknowledging communication needs. An absolute prohibition seems excessive and could damage student-administrator relations.  In conclusion, I believe Policy 1 offers the wisest path forward. It empowers students through reasonable trust but also maintains focus on school priorities when most important. Overall learning, well-being and school culture are best served through this balanced, pragmatic option. Thank you for considering my perspective on this important topic.		1
 The electoral college is a system used in the United States to select the president and vice president. It is a process that has been in place since the founding of the country and has been a subject of debate and controversy for many years. The question of whether the electoral college works has become even more prominent in recent years as technology has allowed for more accurate and timely tracking of voter turnout and preferences.  There are some who argue that the electoral college is an outdated and ineffective system that no longer represents the will of the people. They argue that the system is biased in favor of certain states, such as those with smaller populations, and that it doesn't give equal weight to the needs and preferences of every citizen. They also argue that the system can lead to the candidate "campaigning" only in a few key swing states, ignoring the needs and concerns of voters in other parts of the country.  Others, however, argue that the electoral college is an important part of the democratic process. They argue that it provides a stable and consistent system for selecting the president and that it helps to ensure the president is elected by the entire country, not just by voters in a few key states. They also argue that the system allows for smaller, more representative electorates, which can help to prevent the dominance of big cities and states in the selection of the president.  While the debate about the effectiveness of the electoral college is ongoing, there is no denying that it has played an important role in the history of the United States. It has allowed the country to elect a president and vice president who are elected by the entire country and not just by a few key states. The system may not be perfect, and there may be areas where it needs to be improved, but overall, it is a system that has served the country well for over two centuries.  In conclusion, the effectiveness of the electoral college is a complex issue that has been debated for many years. While there are certainly valid arguments to be made on both sides of the debate, it is clear that the electoral college is an important part of the democratic process in the United States. As such, it is important that any proposals for reforming the system take into account its strengths and weaknesses and work to create a system that represents the will of the majority of the country's citizens.		1

I believe that dress codes are beneficial to the school environment. There are several reasons why I take this position.   Firstly, dress codes help to promote a sense of equality and fairness among students. When all students are required to adhere to the same dress code, it eliminates the pressure to wear expensive or trendy clothing. This means that students from different socioeconomic backgrounds are less likely to feel excluded or marginalized based on their clothing choices.  Secondly, dress codes can help to reduce distractions in the classroom. When students are dressed appropriately for school, they are less likely to be preoccupied with how they look or what they are wearing. This can help them to focus on their studies and be more productive in class.  Lastly, dress codes can instill a sense of discipline and professionalism among students. By requiring students to dress in a particular way, it sends a message that school is a place for learning and that students should take their education seriously.  For example, when our school implemented a dress code last year, we noticed a significant improvement in the overall behavior and attitudes of our students. Fewer distractions, improved focus, and a more professional attitude created a more positive learning environment for everyone.  In conclusion, while some students may not like the idea of a dress code, I believe that the benefits far outweigh any potential drawbacks. By promoting equality, reducing distractions, and instilling discipline, dress codes can be an effective tool for creating a positive learning environment in schools.		1

 Thomas Jefferson's statement, "Determine never to be idle...it is wonderful how much may be done if we are always doing," emphasizes the importance of being active and constantly striving towards something. By always working towards a goal, we can discover new things and become more aware of the world around us.  Jefferson's belief in the value of hard work is evident in his statement that "working hard to get something feels so much more cherishable." This suggests that the satisfaction we get from achieving our goals is greater than the satisfaction we get from simply waiting for things to happen.  Furthermore, Jefferson's statement that "not doing anything is bad because you are just wasting your time and sometimes other peoples time too" highlights the negative consequences of inactivity. When we are not working towards a goal, we are not making progress and we are not using our time effectively.  An example of the benefits of being active is when a student works hard to improve their grades in order to get into a better college. By striving towards this goal, the student is able to achieve a higher level of education and potentially open up more opportunities in the future.  In some situations, inactivity may be necessary, such as when someone is going through a difficult time and needs to focus on their mental health. However, in general, being active and working towards a goal is the most ideal approach.  In conclusion, Thomas Jefferson's statement highlights the importance of being active and constantly striving towards something. By working hard and making progress, we can achieve our goals and discover new things about the world around us.		1
Graduating high school in four or three years has potential advantages and drawbacks that must be considered when making the decision to pursue the shortened schedule. Summer classes are an option for those looking to graduate early, but it is important to weigh the reasons one might not want to take courses during the summer, such as exhaustion from taking classes during the school year or wanting to pursue other interests such as a job or a summer internship.   Elective classes are a great way to round out a high school educational experience. Electives may include art, music, foreign language, and other courses not typically part of the traditional curriculum. These classes may have an advantage in terms of helping a student stand out in the college application process.   Additional factors influencing student decisions include working to save money for college and the cost of supplies such as textbooks. Graduating high school early could ease the financial burden, but the amount of coursework students may miss could have a negative impact on their college readiness. Ultimately, students must consider potential financial, time, and educational implications when determining how valuable an early graduation timeline will be for their academic future.		1

By asking your friends, family, or even a gaming influencer on social media, you can get a bunch of different perspectives and opinions. Maybe one of your friends has played it and can tell you if it's any good, or maybe a gaming influencer can give you a more objective view since they've played a bunch of different games.  But it's not just about video games! Asking multiple people for advice can be helpful in any situation. Like, let's say you're trying to decide which club to join at school. You could just pick the one that seems the most fun, but by asking other kids in the club or even a teacher, you can get a better idea of what it's actually like. Maybe you'll find out that the club you thought was the most fun is actually super competitive and stressful, or maybe you'll learn that the club you never considered is actually really chill and fun.  Another cool thing about asking multiple people for advice is that you can get a more well-rounded view of the situation. Like, if you're trying to decide what college to go to, you could ask people who went to different colleges and get a feel for what it's like at each one. Maybe you'll find out that one college has a great program for your major, but the campus is really small and you wouldn't have as many opportunities to meet new people. Or maybe you'll find out that another college has a super fun social scene, but the classes are really hard.  So, in conclusion, asking multiple people for advice is super helpful because it gives you a bunch of different perspectives and opinions. Distance learning can provide many benefits to students and teachers. I feel, students should have the choice of deciding if distance learning or traditional learning is the right fit for them. Almost, every student will be eager to take their classes online. Not everyone will agree with my opinion, but here is why I strongly believe students should follow through with distance learning. By taking classes online, students will benefit by being given the choice to waking up when they desire. It will teach students better time management skills. As well as, being able to take their time on learning a new unit without feeling rushed. I think students will excel and benefit from attend school online rather than physically attending school  To begin, a benefit from attending class from home is, waking up whenever you desire. Students should have the choice to get out of bed when their body is well rested enough to start the day. For example, some schools start at 7:15 a. m. meaning, in order to have a well breakfast, time to get ready, and arrive at school on time, will expect the student to wake up even earlier to have time to complete their morning checklist. First impressions are often the initial judgments we make about a person, place, or thing. They are formed quickly and can be difficult to change. However, research has shown that first impressions are not impossible to change. In this essay, I will explore the effects of culture, practice, and adjustment on first impressions and present evidence to support the idea that first impressions can be altered.  Culture plays a significant role in shaping first impressions. Different cultures have different norms, values, and beliefs that influence how people perceive the world around them. For example, in some cultures, it is considered impolite to make direct eye contact, while in others, it is seen as a sign of respect. If someone from a culture that values direct eye contact were to meet someone from a culture that sees direct eye contact as impolite, they may form a negative first impression of each other. However, with practice and adjustment, this first impression can be changed. For example, if someone from the culture that values direct eye contact were to spend time with someone from the culture that sees direct eye contact as impolite, they may learn to adjust their behavior and make indirect eye contact, leading to a more positive first impression.  Practice also plays a crucial role in changing first impressions. When we encounter new experiences or people, our brains form initial judgments based on the information available to us. However, as we continue to interact with the person or experience, our brain processes more information and can adjust our first impression accordingly. For example, if someone meets someone who they initially thought was rude and aloof, but who later proves to be kind and caring, their first impression may change. This change in first impression is due to the practice of continuing to interact with the person and processing more information about them.  Adjustment is also an essential factor in changing first impressions. When we encounter new experiences or people, our brains form initial judgments based on the information available to us. However, if we later learn that our initial judgment was incorrect, our brain can adjust our first impression accordingly. For example, if someone meets someone who they initially thought was unintelligent, but who later proves to be highly intelligent, their first impression may change. This change in first impression is due to the adjustment of their initial judgment based on new information.  In conclusion, first impressions are not impossible		1
 Dear Senator,  I am writing to express my support for keeping the Electoral College as the current method for electing the President of the United States. While I understand the arguments in favor of changing to a popular vote, I believe that the Electoral College system provides several important benefits that make it a preferable choice.  First and foremost, the Electoral College ensures that every vote counts. In a popular vote system, the candidate who wins in a few large, densely populated states could potentially win the popular vote, even if they fail to win the electoral vote. This could result in a candidate who does not represent the will of the majority of the American people being elected President. Under the Electoral College, however, a candidate must win the support of a majority of the electors in order to be elected, which means that every vote counts, regardless of where it is cast.  Additionally, the Electoral College system encourages candidates to campaign in all 50 states, not just in a few key swing states. This ensures that candidates are not only focused on winning the support of voters in a few key regions, but are also paying attention to the needs and concerns of voters across the country. This diversity of focus is an important aspect of a healthy democracy, as it ensures that candidates are not only focused on winning the support of a few key groups, but are also considering the needs and concerns of a broad range of voters.  Furthermore, the Electoral College system provides a level of certainty in the outcome of the election. While it is possible for a candidate to win the popular vote but lose the electoral vote, this has only happened in a handful of rare instances. In contrast, a popular vote system could potentially result in a situation where no candidate wins a clear majority, leading to a protracted and uncertain period of time before a president can be elected. This level of uncertainty is not desirable in a democratic system, and the Electoral College provides a level of certainty that is lacking in a popular vote system.  In conclusion, I believe that the Electoral College system provides several important benefits that make it a preferable choice for electing the President of the United States. It ensures that every vote counts, encourages candidates to campaign in all 50 states, and provides a level of certainty in the outcome of the election. While there may be arguments in favor of changing to a popular vote system, I believe that the Electoral College is a more effective and equitable method for electing the President of the United States.  Sincerely,  [Your Name]		1
Dear Principal,  Imagine you were a kid at school, and you forgot it was a shortened day. You need to call your parents but, no, you can't because your principal decided to ban cell phones all together. Now what? For this reason, I strongly support Policy 1. In case of emergencies or even to make sure of an after-school event, phones could be in great use. With Policy 2 in act, you could be staying in school for many hours until your ride picks you up.  In case of an emergency, a phone would be great to have. What if, during lunch, my friend breaks a bone or gets an asthma attack. There would be no time to call a teacher for help and even if they did come, what would they do for help? Any student's first instinct would be to take out their phone and call 911. Once your done with that, you tell your friend to call a teacher from somewhere so that they can handle the situation. "Whew," you say. "thankfully I had my cell phone."  Should students have partnerships with companies that align with their career goals? Students often believe that working with various businesses is beneficial to their future prospects. If a student is uncertain about their career path, partnerships with companies can help them gain clarity and direction. Students should form partnerships with companies because they can gain valuable skills and knowledge about their desired career, learn more about the industry they are interested in, and determine if the job they want is truly the right fit for them.  First, partnerships with companies can provide students with the opportunity to gain practical experience and skills relevant to their desired career. By working alongside professionals in the field, students can learn how to apply theoretical concepts to real-world situations. They can also gain insights into the day-to-day operations of a company, which can help them make more informed decisions about their career path.  Second, partnerships with companies can provide students with a deeper understanding of the industry they are interested in. By working with a company, students can gain a more nuanced understanding of the industry, including its challenges, opportunities, and trends. This can help them make more informed decisions about their career path and prepare them for the challenges they may face in the future.  Third, partnerships with companies can help students determine if the job they want is truly the right fit for them. Similar to the other two points, this helps them, but not only if they want to pursue in that job. Also, they can find a backup plan if that business is not the right one for them. They can go see if it's a bad business, if it helps with the future, and if it's the job they want to go after. They can't focus on that one thing if they don't see it for themselves, they're going to find something that they want to do not what they need to do.  In conclusion, partnerships with companies can be a valuable resource for students looking to gain skills, knowledge, and experience relevant to their desired career. By working with a company, students can gain practical experience, a deeper understanding of the industry, and determine if the job they want is truly the right fit for them. While there may be those who argue that working with a company will not provide any value, the benefits of partnerships cannot be overstated. Climate change has become a significant issue in recent years, with many arguing that governments should take immediate action to address it. While some believe that this is a problem that needs to be addressed urgently, others argue that there are other more pressing issues that require attention. In this essay, I will argue in favor of the idea that governments should take immediate action to address climate change.  Firstly, the effects of climate change are becoming increasingly evident, with rising sea levels, increased frequency and severity of natural disasters, and changes in weather patterns. The impact of these changes is felt not only in the environment but also in the economy, with industries such as agriculture, tourism, and fishing being affected. If governments do not take action to address climate change, the situation is likely to worsen, and the effects will become more severe.  Secondly, the cost of inaction is likely to be much higher than the cost of taking action. The economic costs of natural disasters and the damage caused by climate change are already significant, and these costs are likely to increase if nothing is done. On the other hand, taking action to address climate change may require an initial investment, but it is likely to be much less than the cost of dealing with the consequences of inaction.  Finally, taking action to address climate change is not only necessary but also presents opportunities for economic growth and development. Investing in renewable energy sources and promoting sustainable practices can create new jobs and boost economic growth. It can also promote innovation and technological advancement, which can have far-reaching benefits for society.  In conclusion, the issue of climate change is a significant problem that requires immediate action. Governments must take action to address this problem, not only to mitigate the effects of climate change but also to promote economic growth and development. While there may be costs associated with taking action, the cost of inaction is likely to be much higher. Therefore, it is essential that we act now to address climate change and ensure a sustainable future for generations to come.		1

Okay, here's my attempt at writing an essay as an 8th grade student:  Pros and Cons of Allowing Schools with Older and Younger Students  As I sit here thinking about the topic of schools with older and younger students, I can't help but think of my own school experience. I've been in middle school for a few years now, and I've seen my fair share of younger and older students. Some schools have programs that allow younger students to attend, while others have programs that allow older students to come in. But what are the pros and cons of these programs, and how can we make them successful?  One pro of having schools with older and younger students is that it can help with socialization. Younger students can learn from older students, and older students can teach them important life skills. For example, older students can teach younger students how to play sports, how to study for tests, and how to be responsible. This can help younger students feel more comfortable in school and make friends more easily.  Another pro is that it can help with academic achievement. Older students can help younger students with their schoolwork, and younger students can learn from older students' experiences. For example, older students can help younger students with math problems, and younger students can learn about the importance of hard work and dedication.  However, there are also some cons to having schools with older and younger students. One con is that it can be difficult for older students to focus on their own schoolwork. They may feel like they have to take care of the younger students, which can be frustrating for them. Another con is that younger students may not take the older students seriously, which can lead to disruptions in the classroom.  To make a successful program, I think schools should have clear rules and expectations for both older and younger students. For example, older students should be expected to help younger students, but they should also be given time to focus on their own schoolwork. Younger students should be taught to respect older students and take their help seriously.  In conclusion, having schools with older and younger students can be beneficial for both groups, but it's important to have clear rules and expectations in place to make the program successful. By allowing older and younger students to learn from each other, we can create a more		1

Many students express dissatisfaction with the current policy that requires a minimum grade of B to participate in sports and other extracurricular activities. As a student, I believe that this policy is unfair and should be changed.  Dear principal, I urge you to reconsider the current policy of requiring a minimum grade of B to participate in sports or other extracurricular activities. This policy is not fair to all students, as some may have other responsibilities or challenges that make it difficult to maintain a B average. Additionally, many students believe that sports and other extracurricular activities are an important part of their education and personal development, and should be accessible to all students regardless of their academic standing.  In my opinion, the current policy is not fair to all students. Some students may have other responsibilities or challenges that make it difficult to maintain a B average. For example, some students may have to work part-time or take care of family members, which can make it difficult to maintain a high academic standing. Additionally, some students may have learning disabilities or other challenges that make it difficult to maintain a high grade point average.  Furthermore, many students believe that sports and other extracurricular activities are an important part of their education and personal development. Participating in sports and other extracurricular activities can help students develop important skills such as teamwork, leadership, and discipline. Additionally, these activities can be a fun and enjoyable way for students to socialize and make new friends.  In conclusion, I believe that the current policy of requiring a minimum grade of B to participate in sports and other extracurricular activities is unfair and should be changed. I urge the principal to reconsider this policy and make it more accessible to all students, regardless of their academic standing. Thank you for your attention to this matter.		1
